with cm-size (~30 cm) well-sorted sandstone layers between the two volcanic units (Fig. 11C). Some contacts between the silicic rocks are more complex. For example, in Figure 12A the older unit is composed of large, angular to sub-rounded fragments of a highly vesiculated vitrophyre. The fragments are cm- to meter sized, contain large amygdales (~2–10 cm) filled by quartz and have borders with different degrees of oxidation. The groundmass between the fragments is a vesic- ulated altered oxidized vitrophyre (Fig. 12B). This vitrophyre has minor vesicles (mm- to cm-size) and is cross-cut by a poorly-vesiculated vitrophyre dyke. The dyke is 1 m thick and is associated with quartz venules associated, indicat- ing normal displacement with a southeast top with slightly oblique components (Fig. 12C). The oxidized vitrophyres are covered by a porphyritic grey vitrophyre with foliation also dipping southeast (Fig. 12D).

This sharp contact between upper basalt-andesite flows with the grey flat-lying flows of Palmas Formation is very frequently recognized through- out the southern Paraná Basin in elevations between ~350- 880 m (Umann et al. 2001, Lima et al. 2012, Waichel et al. 2012, Rossetti et al. 2014, Barreto et al. 2014, Polo & Janasi 2014, Rossetti et al. 2017, Simões et al., 2017).
Even though no contact between oxidized vitrophyres over basaltic flows were observed, the field relations illus- trated in Figures 2 and 3 are our support to assume that the former unit is younger than the second. Thus, oxidized vitrophyres are the basal silicic unit, lying over the mafic units and are covered by grey flat-lying silicic vitrophyres.
Banded vitrophyres are regionally exposed along an ~6 km width, NW-trending structure (Fig. 2). According to the distribution of structures in contours, they occur either below or above oxidized vitrophyres and always have a grey vitrophyre unit above them, the contact between the units, however, is frequently absent. Outcrops showing these vit- rophyres as dike-like structures, along with the presence of oxidized vitrophyres and breccias toward the borders of the expositions and the association of the inferred intrusive units with regional tectonic structures are arguments for interpret- ing them as conduits.
Flow morphologies Flow morphologies and physical characteristics of the
subaerial silicic vitrophyres are divided between oxidized and grey units. Both share incomplete characterization because the total area calculation of the flows is difficult due to fault occurrence and cannot be estimated by using conventional remote sensing tools. However, it is inferred from field observations and outcrop elevation correlation that grey flat-lying vitrophyres (Gv) must reach an extent area greater than 30 km2.
In the oxidized vitrophyres (Fig. 13A), typical base struc- tures such as autobreccias, pipe vesicles and vesicular crusts were not found. By outcrop correlation and comparison with other types of subaerial flows, the poorly-vesiculated vitrophyre with flat-lying foliation (Figs. 5A and 5B) rep- resents the core of the flow unit. Toward the top of the flow, the vesiculation degree rises, the size of the vesicles variate more (Figs. 5C and 5D) and in the upper crust, which is observed in contact with upper grey flows, the vesicles have uniform and smaller sizes (Figs. 5E and 5F).

EMPLACEMENT OF THE VOLCANIC UNITS
Rheology Both oxidized and grey vitrophyres have distinguishing
features more compatible with extensive lava flows (e.g., Henry
& Wolff 1992). Other similar silicic units in the south of the province have also been recognized as lavas (Umann et al. 2001, Polo & Janasi 2014, Simões et al. 2014, Guimarães et al. 2015). The extension and uniformity of these types of flow are observed in dacite flows with well insulated crusts, allowing even high viscosity magma to attain great distances (Harris & Rowland 2009). A system sustained at high effu- sion rates is also important to form long simple lava flows (Walker 1971; Walker 1973).
A significant rheological property of the Paraná-Etendeka LIP silicic volcanics is the very high pre- and syn-eruptive temperatures, obtained by apatite saturation and pyroxene-liq- uid geothermometry data, in the order of 1,000–1,100ºC as well as low relative viscosities for rhyodacite-rhyolite magmas (Milner et al. 1992, Bellieni et al. 1984, 1986, Garland et al. 1995, Janasi et al. 2007, Simões et al. 2014). Low viscosity is a favorable property for efficient magma flow, emplaced at long distances.
The viscosity of the magma is related to gas loss during eruption; the magma ascent rate is also sensitive to this loss. As the volume proportion of gas affects magma density, com- pressibility and rheology, it results in both horizontal and vertical pressure gradients in the magma column to allow gas to escape (Sparks 2003).

According to the Massol & Jaupart model (1999), if bubbles are interconnected gases can escape to the con- duit walls. In rhyolite lavas, high porosity bands are often developed. Therefore, they potentially act as pathways for gas movement to the lava surface (Sparks 2003, Houghton et al. 2010, Furukawa & Uno 2015). A volatile-rich magma is less dense than a degassed magma, both because of reduced dissolved volatiles within the melt (Richet et al. 2000) and (at low pressure) because of the presence of an exsolved fluid phase (Witham 2011). When we analyze the mapped units as a whole, the banding, shearing and fragmentation of magma described in variable parts of the conduit outcrops, more commonly in their borders can be interpreted as favorable paths to degassing. Sustained high
temperatures and consequently low viscosity could be held by a competent heat flux.
Conditioning structures for the conduit system
A plausible explanation of why the conduit-related rocks were not observed cutting the lower basaltic units is because their outcrops are controlled by tectonic structures. The conduits are regionally exposed, mostly in the south, near the Antas river bed (Fig. 1). This river forms a curved NE-SW structure comprising a set of normal and transcurrent faults (Fig. 2). In the south of the river, the NW-trending structures contain the conduit expositions. It resembles the São Marcos (Lima et al. 2012, 2017, Simões et al. 2017) and

Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul areas (Simões et al. 2015, 2017), both also south of this NE-SW structure. The observed banding is folded several times (Figs. 6C, 7A, 7B, 7D, 8). F1- and F2-phase folds are generally present in the center of the conduits, with sub-vertical disposal of the axial sur- faces. Toward the margins, a variety of fold phases is gener- ated (at least four) mainly by mixing between more and less oxidized bands (Fig. 7D). Thus, a complex arrangement of flow directions within the conduits is recognized.
One regional scale, the geometrical and kinematical interpretation of transcurrent faults made by Nummer et al. (2011), shows that the NW-SE faults with sinistral strike-slip movement are older (Eocretaceous) than NE-SW faults with dextral and NW-SE faults with sinistral relative movements in the northeast of Rio Grande do Sul. The fault reactivation in NE-SW direction coincides with Precambrian structures like the Porto Alegre suture and Dorsal de Canguçu shear zone (Fernandes et al. 1995). Additionally, the NE-trending Antas Lineament can be correlated to the NE-SW orien- tation of Huab, Ugab and several other rivers in Namibia. We interpret that the role of major NE-SW structural reac- tivation is fundamental to open spaces at NW-SE faults, the dominant trend of conduit area outcrops in this study.
Considering the tectonic setting for the Paraná Basin, the thermomechanical study of Quintas et al. (1999) concludes that the major extension of the basin occurred in the Permo- Carboniferous. In the Juro-Cretaceous, during volcanism, the subsidence was associated to reactivation of older struc- tures allied with a thermal component. The thermal compo- nent, considered to be plume-related (Hawkesworth et al. 1992, Peate 1997, Gibson et al. 2006), was connected to the surface through a feeder system that is proposed to reach the mantle at ~35 km, at least in the northern portion of the
basin (Molina et al. 1988). This indicates that emplacement of the conduits in the shallow crust must be a reflection of a deeper feeder system.
The injection of magma through dykes during gravita- tional displacement of blocks is evidenced in Figure 12A and may have played an important role in magma trans- port. In the places where the dykes intruded on more friable rocks, at the valleys of the mapped area, the main intrusive structure remain preserved (see Figs. 6A and 6B). The evo- lution from the syneclise phase to pre-rift in the Paraná Basin, increasing the regional extension, is an appropriate scenario fostering the propagation of normal fault sets and the reactivation of older structures.
Crustal extension is generally followed by basin cool- ing (McKenzie 1978, Latin & White 1993), but this does not appear to be the case for the Paraná Basin, where the thermal component remained active. We believe that in the Paraná-Etendeka LIP the movements in regional faults triggered the silicic magma ascent through regional-scale conduit systems.
Geological model for Mato Perso Conduit System
The vitrophyre relative chronology observed in the field favors the hypothesis that oxidized vitrophyres are cut by the conduits. These contain oxidized vitrophyre fragments with variable vesiculation patterns. Transition frombreccias,- most oftenly, and more oxidized vitrophyre in the borders to grey/black vitrophyre intruding them on the center of the conduits, presence of oxidized bands only in the base of the grey vitrophyres and mixing features between vitro- phyres lead us to infer that the described conduits fed at least the upper grey vitrophyre units (Fig. 14).

The Mato Perso Conduit System
CONCLUSIONS
In conclusion, in the Mato Perso area, the silicic vol- canic succession overlying the basaltic units of the Vale do Sol Formation, Serra Geral Group, comprises oxi- dized vitrophyres at the base which are cut and locally incorporated by banded vitrophyres. The conduit sys- tem fed the upper grey flat-lying vitrophyres. Subaerial flows are similar to extensive lava flows described in lit- erature, suggesting large emplacement areas. The conduit paths in the crust were conditioned by the normal and oblique faults developed during extensional stages com- bined with a thermal component in the Paraná Basin. A system sustained at high temperatures ensured that the
silicic magma remained in low viscosity during ascent and the emplacement of the upper grey vitrophyre units was driven by effusion rates sufficient for enabling the lava to run at long distances.

Abstract 13
The silicic volcanics of the Paraná-Etendeka large igneous province (LIP) occurs extensively in southern Brazil, where 14
feeder conduits and lava flows were recognized with different lithofacies architecture. In this work we compare magmatic 15
flow structures measured in the field to anisotropy of magnetic susceptibility (AMS) data at eleven conduit and lava flow 16
sites. Conduit sites gave mean flat-lying kmax, suggesting horizontal flow. High dispersion of the magnetic susceptibility 17
axes in some sites is explained considering obstruction of flow by fragments and complex folding patterns. Silicic lavas 18
show flat-lying kmax-kint planes with kmax plunging to NE, NW, SE and SW. Viscosity of magma was calculated at 1000°C 19
to for three H2O content threshold: dry (10 6.6
Pas), 0.5% (10 5.1
Pas) and 1.3% (10 3.8
Pas). Low bubble content in lava flows 20
and central part of conduits is favorable to decrease the capillary number Ca and the dynamic capillary number Cd, keeping 21
the initial calculated viscosity. These domains have low content of fragments and less than two folding phases, representing 22
potential zones where the magnetic fabric is parallel to the flow. In the boarder of the conduits larger shear rates, high 23
fragment and bubble content inducing the unsteadiness of the flow (high Ca and Cd) favor random distribution of the 24
magnetic fabric. The path of magma to surface through fault zones was in extensional regime. Constant generation and 25
eruption rates explain the large volume of silicic lavas in the southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP, keeping their low viscosity to 26
run long distances and form extensive units. 27

1 Introduction 35
Development of flow patterns in silicic magma creates a series of structures depending, mainly, on strain rates, temperature 36
variation and volatile content. Foliation and banding are noted as penetrative structures in obsidian flows (Manley & Fink, 37
1987) and several processes were ascribed to generate them, such as magma mixing, stretching and folding, continuous 38
brecciation and welding, microlite variation, vesicularity variation, among others (e.g. Seaman et al. 1995; Castro and 39
Cashmann 1999; Gonnermann and Manga 2005; Perugini and Poli 2012). A wide number of explanations about folding and 40
boudinage of magma in viscous or fragile state can be observed as a result of different flow domains in which 41
compressional, directional or constrictive forces act (e.g. Smith and Houston 1994; Castro and Cashmann 1999; Morrow 42
and McPhie 2000; Morgan et al. 2008) while magma is subjected to progressive deformation (e.g. Smith 1996). Above 43
liquidus temperatures, the rheological response becomes more complex as crystals and bubbles start to grow. In this context, 44
the viscous magma can behave like Bingham fluids (Fink 1983). 45
In the southern portion of the Paraná-Etendeka Large Igneous Province (LIP), the silicic volcanism prior to the Gondwana 46
break-up is dominantly represented by lava flows (Henry and Wolf 1992; Umann et al. 2001; Polo and Janasi 2014; 47
Guimarães et al. 2017; Polo et al. 2017; Simões et al. 2014, 2017; Lima et al. 2012, 2018; Rossetti et al. 2014, 2017) and 48
inferred shallow portion of conduits for some of these flows are described with steeply inclined banding, folding in several 49
scales (from mm- to m-) and intense brecciation (e.g. Lima et al. 2012; 2018; Simões et al. 2017). Subaerial lavas - some 50
recognized as obsidian flows - are dominated by flat-lying distribution of banding, breccias and vesicles, presenting steeply 51
inclined structures only locally. 52
Investigation about magma transport properties revealed that high temperature conditions (> 1000°C) may have affected the 53
viscosity and the mode of emplacement of these silicic flows, maybe differing from more common rhyolitic and dacitic 54
magmas (Garland et al. 1995; Lima et al. 2012; Simões et al. 2014; Polo et al. 2017). 55
The purpose of the present work is to characterize the magmatic flow at occurrences of silicic conduits and lava flows in 56
southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP. For this, we investigate the main structures of these volcanic units in field scale and thin 57
section, and provide an AMS (Anisotropy of Magnetic Susceptibility) study. A brief description of the chemical types, pre-58
eruptive temperatures and magma viscosity is yielded in order to discuss the magma transport properties and to further 59
describe the conduit magma flow and its behavior during subaerial emplacement of lava. 60
61
1.1 Geological setting 62
The Paraná-Etendeka LIP occupies an area of 917,000±15,000 km² (Frank et al. 2009) of which 90% is located in South 63
America and 10% is in Africa (Fig. 1a), above the aeolian sedimentary rocks of Botucatu and Etjo formations. In South 64
America the Paraná-Etendeka LIP comprises a 1700 m-thick association of tholeiitic magmas (Melfi et al. 1988), with 65
basaltic to intermediate lavas, dykes and sills prevalent (97.5% of total volume) over silicic units (2.5%). The volcanic units 66
of Paraná-Etendeka LIP are represented by the Serra Geral Group and in southern Brazil, they have chemically more 67
primitive compound and simple pahoehoe basaltic flows in the base, represented by the Torres Formation (Rossetti et al. 68
2017). Vertically stacked sheet-like rubbly pahoehoe basaltic flows of the Vale do Sol Formation cover the compound flows 69
and represents the more voluminous basalt lava unit. The silicic volcanics cover these basalt flows and are represented by 70
3
the Palmas Formation. The last volcanic manifestations in the area are the compound and simple oxidized basaltic flows of 71
the Esmeralda Formation (Rossetti et al. 2017). 72
In a regional scale, the distribution of the Paraná-Etendeka LIP volcanic rocks is made by the classification of mafic and 73
silicic types, based in their TiO2 content (e.g. Bellieni et al. 1984; Peate et al. 1992). In the case of the silicic rocks, the ones 74
presenting high-Ti (TiO2 > 2 wt.%) are called Chapecó-type magmas (Peate et al. 1992) and are exposed in the northern 75
portion of the basin, between the NW-SE trending Ponta Grossa arch and the Torres structural valley (Fig. 1b). In the 76
southern portion, where the studied areas outcrop, the low-Ti (TiO2 <2 wt.%) silicic terms are classified as dacites and 77
rhyolites presenting no more than ~10 vol.% of phenocrysts called Palmas-type magmas. 78
Further, towards the south of the LIP, a small area (3.2 km³) of peraluminous dacitic lavas with cordierite, orthopyroxene, 79
plagioclase and ilmenite as liquidus phases (Vieira 1985; Vieira and Roisenberg 1985) occurs in the Jaguarão region. It is 80
located near to major shear zones of Neoproterozoic age that may have been reactivated during Early Cretaceous (Comin-81
Chiaramonti et al. 2010). In Uruguay, the Cretaceous volcanic rocks occur trending NE-SW (Fig. 1b) and the chemical 82
compositions are also bimodal. The basic Santa Lucía type has Ocean Island Basalts (OIB) geochemical signatures and the 83
Treinta Y Trés type is broadly similar to the low-Ti Gramado lavas (Kirstein et al. 2000). Silicic rocks are dacites to 84
rhyolites from Lavalleja Series (high Ti/Zr, low Nb/Y, higher Sr and Nd isotope ratios) and Aigua Series (high Rb/Sr, high 85
Rb/Ba, high Th). 86
Parts of the plumbing system for basaltic and silicic lavas in southern Brazil are represented by the NW-SE trending Ponta 87
Grossa and the NE-SW trending Santa Catarina and São Paulo dyke swarms (e.g. Raposo 1998, 2017; Florisbal et al. 2014). 88
In Rio Grande do Sul state; postulated conduit systems for silicic lavas were described to the south of a curved NE- trending 89
structure called Antas Lineament (Simões et al. 2017). This structure is parallel to the main regional structures, like NE-SW 90
trending Precambrian Porto Alegre Suture (Fernandes et al. 1995) or younger faults cutting the basin as Leão and Açotea 91
faults (Zalán et al. 1991). 92
In the present study, the investigation of low-field AMS fabric and rheological characterization were carried out in three 93
key-areas where postulated conduits and related lava flows outcrop near each other (Fig. 2a, b). In northeast of Rio Grande 94
do Sul state the conduits outcrop in several elevations, since 400 m to ~ 950 m. Each conduit system and related lava flow 95
units display characteristic lithofacies architecture (Simões et al. 2017), as will be demonstrated in the results section. 96

1.2 Emplacement and correlation of silicic units in Paraná-Etendeka LIP 104
The silicic volcanics of the Serra Geral Group were firstly described as volatile-poor and high-temperature rheomorphic 105
ignimbrites. Arguments used include their laterally persistent sheet-like nature and the absence of typical ignimbrite textures 106
even near the top and base of each unit, which was attributed to obliteration by intense welding (Bellieni et al. 1986; Melfi 107
et al. 1988; Petrini et al. 1989; Roisenberg 1989; Garland et al. 1995; Milner et al. 1995; Bryan et al. 2010). Milner et al. 108
(1995) proposed the correlation of some subgroups of Palmas magma-type with the Namibian quartz latites. The intrusive, 109
circular Messum Complex, was identified as a potential emission center (Milner and Duncan 1987; Milner et al. 1992; 110
Ewart et al. 1998; Ewart et al. 2002), even though the thickness of the silicic volcanic sequence is inferior in the African 111
counterpart. In these models, the silicic deposits in South America would need to have traveled >300 km from their source 112
and been deposited as extensive pyroclastic density currents (e.g. Milner et al. 1995; Bryan et al. 2010). 113
Typical pyroclastic deposits in this LIP are found in the Mesozoic (132 – 124 Ma) Arequita Formation (AF), Uruguay, and 114
described by Muzio et al. (2009). The AF contains high SiO2 (>72 wt.%) lava flows with quartz, K-feldspar and sodic 115
plagioclase phenocrysts. Pyroclastic deposits are confined to the east of the N20°E trending India Muerta Lineament and are 116
consisted of pyroclastic breccias, lappili tuffs and monomitic breccias. 117
5
In southern Brazil, the paucity of pyroclastic lithofacies, with recognition of only local pyroclastic textures in extensive 118
petrographic studies (Comin-Chiaramonti et al. 1988), together with the regional description of coherent and autoclastic 119
lithofacies in a variety of lava bodies (lobes, domes and flows) led other authors to suggest that the silicic deposits are 120
predominantly effusive (Henry and Wolf 1992; Umann et al. 2001; Lima et al. 2012; Polo and Janasi 2014; Simões et al. 121
2014, 2017; Guimarães et al. 2017; Polo et al. 2017a,b). Other features such sand and mud peperites found in both Palmas- 122
and Chapecó-type lava flows favor to the lava flow interpretation also in the center of the LIP (e.g. Lucchetti et al. 2014). 123
Feeder conduits for silicic lavas were firstly proposed and described in quarries at the city of São Marcos, Rio Grande do 124
Sul (Lima et al. 2012, 2018; De Campos et al. 2016). In this region, the rhyodacites have compound magmatic foliation 125
revealed by the alternation of different crystallinity and oxidation grades (Lima et al. 2012). Fragmentation involving 126
rheomorphic and re-melting events described were assigned by De Campos et al. (2016) to parallel oscillations in a very 127
efficient magma ascent system together with high heat flux for conduit system evolution. Other interpretation of the São 128
Marcos outcrops; based in AMS fabrics, showing dominant flat-lying orientation of Kmax is of thermal erosion from lavas 129
that developed sort of a peperite of underlying flow fragments (Cañon-Tapia and Raposo 2017). 130
In other areas at the northeast of Rio Grande do Sul (Mato Perso, Jaquirana and Cambará do Sul) the inferred conduits 131
exhibit lithofacies architecture with banded vitrophyres containing variably vesicular fragments grading laterally into 132
breccias. These structures have dominant sub-vertical orientations trending to NE-SW and NW-SE (Simões et al. 2017). In 133
a regional scale, these conduit outcrops are elongated NW-SE to NE-SW shapes, being covered by flat-lying silicic lava 134
flows (Lima et al. 2012; Simões et al. 2017a,b). 135
136
1.3 Conduits and lava flows 137
In field scale the structural patterns present in the conduits are shared by most expositions. They have near-vertical banding 138
(Fig. 2 c,d) in the central and more resistant part, generally composed of grey to black vitrophyre. Toward the boarders of 139
the outcrops it is notable the mixing of this dark rock with a oxidized vitrophyre (Lima et al. 2012; De Campos et al. 2016; 140
Simões et al. 2017a in press). The mixing patterns can be dominantly chaotic (De Campos et al. 2016), where several 141
folding phases are seemingly like the mixing of two fluids in 2D (e.g. Ottino 1989). Despite these mixing features, 142
recognized in outcrop scale, there is a NE-SW to NW-SE trending of the major unfolded sub-vertical banding. In the 143
external parts of the conduits the vitrophyres mix and acquire several colors in the red and grey scales, surrounding red 144
vitrophyre fragments. Fragments are common features in different parts of the conduits, sometimes with meter-size near the 145
center but more abundant in the boarder, with few to dozens of centimeters, where welding of the fragments may be also 146
found. Vesiculation patterns in conduits are not the marker of the banding but they follow the banding and fold axial 147
surfaces orientation (Simões et al. 2017). Where the banding is vertical, the vesicles tend to have the inverse gout shape, 148
i.e., pointing to the paleo-surface. 149
The lava flows have structures like dominant flat-lying foliation related to an incipient and locally recognized magmatic 150
banding (Fig. 2e). Their vesicles are frequently tube-shaped near the base and spherical-shaped toward the top of the flows. 151
Oxidized lava flows under the conduits also display a vesiculated frothy top (Simões et al. 2018 in press). 152
6
The aim of AMS determination in this study is to compare the behavior of the magnetic fabric in those outcrops considered 153
to be feeder conduits and in those interpreted as lava flows. We choose three key-areas for sampling: the exposition of a 154
banded obsidian lava flow in a dimension stone quarry placed at Cambará do Sul city (site CM1), which was an opportunity 155
to collect more robust data (42 drill cores) in horizontal and vertical positions; a vertical succession of obsidian flows (sites 156
CM2, 3, 5) and conduit (site CM4) in Jaquirana city (8 – 11 cores/site); a pair of conduits and associated lava flow in the 157
Itaimbezinho (National Park of Aparados da Serra), where 11 and 12 cores per site (IT1 and IT2) were collected; and in a 158
sequence of conduits and lavas near Caxias do Sul city (Mato Perso district), where 10 to 16 cores/site were obtained (sites 159
MS1, 2, 3 and 4). 160

2 METHODS 167
2.1 Anisotropy of Magnetic Susceptibility 168
The measurements involving AMS were obtained in the Laboratory of Magnetic Anisotropies and Rock Magnetism of the 169
Institute of Geosciences – São Paulo University (USP). Each drill core was sliced in approximately 2,2 cm specimens for 170
measurement using an MFK1-FA instrument with 3D rotator of AGICO. The measurement consisted in the application of a 171
low magnetic field (425 A/m) to the sample along its rotation through three orthogonal axes. The AMS orientation of each 172
specimen is represented in the lower hemisphere equal-area stereonets. The average orientations of principal susceptibility 173
axes present in Table 1 are represented by the mean values (large symbols in the stereonets) and were calculated using the 174
Hext-Jelinek statistics (Hext 1963; Jelinek 1978) in the software ANISOFT 4.2 (Chadima and Jelinek 2009). Calculated 175
variables are divided into magnitude and shape parameters. The mean susceptibility tensor (km = kmax+kint+kmin/3) is the 176
average of the total susceptibility of the specimen and the corrected degree of anisotropy (Pj) is assumed as measure of 177
degree of anisotropy. The shape-parameter T defines the eccentricity of the strain ellipsoid where 0 <T ? 1 is referred to 178
oblate shapes and -1 ? T <0 correspond to prolate shapes. This relation can be also observed when plotting the T and Pj 179
parameters (Jelinek 1981; Hrouda 1982). 180
Thermomagnetic curves in an Ar atmosphere were obtained by a CS-4 apparatus coupled to the MFK1-FA and the 181
specimens were progressively heated up to 700°C and subsequently cooled to room temperature. Hysteresis measurements 182
at room temperature were performed using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM—Nuvo, Molspin) in fields up to 1 T. 183
184
2.2 Whole-rock geochemical analysis 185
To calculate estimated temperatures and viscosities a set of whole-rock geochemical analyses was obtained. The analyses 186
were made at Acme Analytical Laboratories LTD., Vancouver, Canada, utilizing analysis routines 4A and 4B. In the first 187
one, the main oxides and several minor elements total abundance were obtained from 0.2 g of analyzed sample by 188
Inductively Coupled Plasma – Emission Spectrometry (ICP-ES) with detection limit of 0.01% for SiO2, Al2O3, Fe2O3, CaO, 189
MgO, Na2O, K2O, MnO, TiO2 and P2O5. In the second one the rare earth and refractory element results were obtained from 190
0.2 g of analyzed sample by ICP – MS (Mass Spectrometry). 191
The apatite saturation model of Harrison & Watson (1984) was used to estimate liquidus temperatures. It is based in 192
experimental data of apatite solubility as function of magma temperature and composition. The model used in this work to 193
estimate the viscosity (Giordano et al. 2008) uses whole-rock chemical compositions input and was made out predicting 194
Newtonian non-Arrhenian temperature dependence of silicate melts. It was calibrated from more than 1770 sample 195
experimental analysis in a wide range of temperatures and magma compositions. The effective H2O content of 1.3 wt.% is 196
an estimated value based in the plagioclase and liquid composition (M.S. Simões, unpublished data). 197

3 Results 201
3.1 Magnetic mineralogy 202
Thermomagnetic curves are present in figure 3 and display slightly different patterns, but in all cases the intensity of 203
susceptibility (k) decreases at 580°C to 600°C. Irreversible curves are the most common; with exception of sample CM3 204
which the cooling curve had approximately the same k values of the heating curve. In the other samples, the curves do not 205
coincide and this response is considered as a product of mineralogical alteration or destruction during the heating. The 206
curves and Curie temperatures near ~580 °C are typical of Ti-poor magnetites, which are also verified in thin section in the 207
form of glomeroporphyritic aggregates of microphenocrysts or dispersed as 0.1 – 0.5 mm microlites. In the site IT01 we 208
obtained curves for oxidized (IT01A) and black (IT01) vitrophyres. The oxidized sample had a slightly decrease in k at ~ 209
350°C and then at ~ 580°C, indicating a probable mixture of Ti-poor magnetite and maghemite, although fine hematite 210
lamellae were observed spread in the groundmass. 211
The presence of ferromagnetic grains is verified by the use of hysteresis curves (Fig. 4). The results of magnetization in 212
VSM yielded Mrs (remanent saturation magnetization), Ms (saturation magnetization), Hc (coercitive force), Hcr (remanent 213
coercivity) values, determined by the application of a decreasing backfield after saturation. Ms and Mrs are from 55.7 to 214
289.2 A/m and 6.5 to 62.5 A/m, respectively. Hc is between 3.4 and 27.0 A/m, while Hcr values range from 13.4 to 46.9 215
A/m. In the Day plot (Day et al. 1977; Dunlop 2002), the bulk of samples lie in the pseudo-single domain (PSD) field (Fig. 216
5). The contribution of magnetic minerals is between 97.7% and 99.8%, and the values of Hc are indicative of fine and 217
coarse fully-saturated Ti-poor magnetite as the dominant carrier of magnetic susceptibility. 218

3.2.2 Site CM1 – Cambará do Sul obsidian flow 258
Near the road to Capão Penso, Cambará do Sul city rural area, in elevations of 990 - 1020 m above the sea level, there are 259
banded vitrophyres with sub-vertical banding striking to NE-SW and NW-SE. Approximately 60 km to northwest of this 260
city, in elevations from 1030 to 1040 m, obsidian flows with flat-lying flow banding, which is locally steeply inclined and 261
folded, dominate and one of them was picked out for AMS sampling .The wide exposure was used as stone dimension 262
quarry, making possible to better observe the structures and to collect a more significant number of core samples in several 263
positions. 264
The obsidian flow has a “boomerang” shape with one arm oriented according NW-SE and another oriented along NE-SW 265

values to SW is parallel to the oblate amygdale orientation (Fig. 7e) and agree with the major disposal of the lava flow (see 276

3.4 RHEOLOGY 405
The rheology of magma controls its ascent, dynamics of conduit flow and the eruption style (Okomura et al. 2016). In 406
present work, magma rheology is used as a complementary investigation to structural and AMS fabric data, since the 407
behavior of silicic magma strongly variate given a wide range of eruptive temperatures, bubble/crystals content and 408
chemical composition (e.g. Cashman 2004; Manga et al. 1998; Mader et al. 2013). 409
410
3.4.1 Temperature and viscosity 411
In order to characterize the chemical types, temperatures and estimated viscosities we selected one sample from each site, 412
except site CM1, for whole-rock geochemical analysis. For this, we chose two samples of coherent vitrophyre of the lava 413
flows (MS-01 and MS-04), one sample of microfractured vitrophyre of one lava flow (MS-22E, equivalent to site CM3), 414
two samples of banded vitrophyre (MS-03A and MS-05b), one sample of a red band (MS-22E, equivalent to site CM4) and 415
one sample of black band (MS-22D, equivalent to site CM4). The chemical analyses are present in Table 2 and cover a 416
range of representative lithofacies from which we collected the drill cores for AMS studies. 417
As seen in Table 2, The bulk of analyzed samples have SiO2 content between 64.78 and 68.18 wt.%. Apatite calculated 418
temperatures are considered to depict the liquidus temperatures of the analyzed vitrophyres, since apatite was one of the 419
first phases to crystallize. P2O5 contents are very similar, varying from 0.25 to 0.28 wt.%. The calculation of Harrison & 420
Watson (1984) thermometer yielded temperatures of 1005.77 – 1088.70°C. Using the model of Giordano et al. (2008), we 421
obtained respective viscosities of these samples by inserting the chemical composition and to the apatite saturation 422
temperatures. Three H2O content thresholds were applied for the viscosity estimation model: dry, 0.5%H2O and 1.3%H2O, 423
the last is considered a best-fit value for the studied samples of Palmas magma-type rhyodacites. Dry viscosity values range 424
between 5.56 and 6.63 log Pa s and drastically decreases to 4.57-6.63 Pa s using 0.5%H2O and 3.88 – 4.58 Pa s with the 425
addition of 1.3% of H2O. 426

3.4.2 Vesiculation, fragments and fragile structures 432
Vesiculation is an important factor to characterize magma rheology and emplacement conditions (Cashman 2004; Blundy 433
and Cashman 2008; Mader et al. 2013 and other references). In the studied outcrops, the patterns of vesiculation degree and 434
vesicle shapes are notably different when comparing conduits and lava flows. In order to quantify the amount of vesicles in 435
macroscopic scale we processed nine outcrop photographs in the ImageJ (Schneider et al. 2012) software and counted 165 436
to 850 points per image, depending on the photograph scale. 437
The coherent vitrophyres from sites MS-01 and MS-04 have 1.9 – 2% of mm-sized spherical vesicles and amygdales. This 438
number must have a little increase near the base of the flow, where pipe vesicles are present (see Fig. 8g). The 439
microfractured vitrophyre of site CM3 gave the lowest value of 0.6% spherical to stretched vesicles with 3-5 mm in size. A 440
red band of site CM-4 has 1.69% of spherical to reverse-drop like mm-sized vesicles, while a grey band presents 4.72 % of 441
dominantly stretched vesicles with few millimeters to 1 – 2 cm in the longest axis. In site CM1 there is a slight variation in 442
the abundance of cm-size oblate amygdales around 4.7%, which seems to be the same case of the top of the flow in site 443
CM-5. Below this top horizon the amount of spherical amygdales is up to 0.96%. 444
The amount of vesicles in the red vitrophyre fragments carried in the magmatic flow banding was also counted. They share 445
common features as 0.5 – 5 mm sizes and stretched shapes, showing random distributions and preferred elongation planes. 446
In site in site MS-2 the fragments have up to 21% of vesicles (Fig. 12a) and in site MS-3 the fragments have 28% CM-4 the 447
fragments vary from 20 to 53% of vesicles. Finally we used a representative count of fragments immersed in the banded 448
vitrophyre and obtained a value of 11.5% in site MS-02 (Fig. 12b) and 16.30 fragment% in site CM4 (Fig. 12c). 449
Fragile structures occur parallel to the banding planes with cm-scale spacing. The structures present strong lineations in 450
non-polished surfaces and display oblique-normal and oblique-reverse movements, while into the bands the magmatic flow 451

4 DISCUSSION 465
4.1 Interpretation of the AMS data 466
4.1.1 Conduits 467
The degree of anisotropy values in the analyzed samples are comparable to those found in sites of high-temperature silicic 468
volcanics (e.g. McPhie et al. 2008; Canón-Tapia and Raposo 2017; Guimarães et al. 2017) and to those obtained in mafic 469
dykes (e.g. Philpotts and Philpotts 2007; Wiegand et al. 2017). In the present work, the sites interpreted as conduit 470
lithofacies display mean degree of anisotropy slightly higher than in the lava flows, contradicting the data presented by 471
Cañón-Tapia and Raposo (2017) at São Marcos city, approximately 60 km west of Mato Perso area. They found smaller 472
degrees of anisotropy in banded vitrophyres than in silicic lava flows. One explanation for this kind of variation is that low 473
degree of anisotropy in evidently deformed magma is experimentally justified in situations where the deformation was taken 474
place at high temperatures or in a complex deformation regime (Cañon-Tapia and Pinkerton 2000). 475
Sites like IT01 and MS2 yielded high dispersion of the susceptibility axes data, showing similarities with the banded 476
vitrophyres of São Marcos (e.g. Cañón-Tapia and Raposo, 2017). Considering field and petrographic data, this random 477
orientation of the magnetic fabric may be result of very complex magmatic flow patterns, as the intense folding resembling 478
the mixture of two liquids (e.g. Ottino, 1989) or because of severe post-magmatic changes in magnetic minerals (Hrouda 479
1985; Raposo 2011). Re-arrangement of the magnetic fabric in the conduit margins should be carried by separation of the 480
flow in different domains of fragment and vesicle contents and in parts of constriction or compression of magma. These 481
changes in stress conditions within the moving magma generating several phases of folding are also causes to explain the 482
high dispersion of kmax, kmin and kint. 483
In conduit sites where the susceptibility axes have more defined clusters, the orientations of kmax are near-horizontal (CM4, 484
MS3), suggesting flat-lying movement of magma along vertical to oblique conduits (Fig. 13). In the case of CM4, complex 485
folding perpendicular to the main banding scatter the orientation of the susceptibility axes, but steeply inclined kmax parallel 486
to the banding measured in field can be found where thick vitrophyre bands are not folded. This is indicative that the 487
magma flow also had a complex structural control, moving vertically only in some locations. In site MS3 there are no 488
individual specimens with vertical kmax, suggesting predominant flat-lying flow. 489
The obstruction of the main magmatic flow by cm- to meter sized fragments (~ 20 – 50%) should be ascribed to the 490
variation of magma flow during segregation different flow domains. The more often presence of these features near the 491
conduit margins suggests that the flow was not uniform and was probably much more complex than in tabular dykes or sills. 492
The mixing of oxidized and non-oxidized magma towards the boarders of the outcrops reveals a flow domain where magma 493
is stretched, folded and the banding changes the direction vertiginously (Figs. 8e, 10c and 11j). Fold patterns observed in 494
the photomicrography of Figure 11j, for example, demonstrate how two parallel flow bands may present horizontal, 495
vertical and oblique banding through polyclinal folding during mixing. 496

4.1.2 Lava flows 500
Silicic lava flows and domes may display near-vertical kmin axes (Cañon-Tapia and Castro 2004), steeply inclined kmax and 501
kmax-kint planes (McPhie et al. 2008), may also exhibit fabric zoning with steep kmax near the conduit zone and flat kmax in 502
the boarders of the flow (Závada et al. 2009) or tilting of the original structures by collapse (Pueyo Anchuela et al. 2014). 503
The rheological homogeneity of the sampled lava flows permitted us to use the magnetic foliations and kmax directions 504
directly to interpret the magmatic flow. The flat-lying disposal of the magnetic foliation in lavas indicate dominant 505
horizontal magmatic flow in sites CM1,2, 3, 5 and IT02 (Fig. 14). Where the flow seems to be laminar and the amygdales 506
display flattened shapes, the shape parameters P and T define oblate ellipsoids. Prolate types are also present and in these 507
cases they are explained by zones of more intense stretching, near the core of the flow. 508
Site CM1 is a good example of how the magnetic fabric behaves in the emplacement of a structurally-controlled lava flow. 509
The magmatic flow represented by the magnetic lineation is parallel to the NW-SE and NE-SW arms of the flow, with kint 510
pointing to SW (Fig. 14). In sites CM2, 3 and 5 kmax is also clustered dipping to NW and SW. The site IT02 has the same 511
kind of distribution of the anisotropy axes, but with kmax pointing to the south. Another interesting feature of this site is the 512
prevalence of oblate magnetic fabrics (Fig. 6), assigned to a possible laminar lava flow. 513
In site MS1 the kmax is also flat-lying, but the girdle of kint and kmax plane forming a prolate shape and the abundance of 514
specimens giving prolate ellipsoids (Fig. 6) indicate that the flow could be channelized, flowing according NW-SE. This is 515
reinforced by the fact that cooling joints recognized in the field are in the outer portions of the flow, confining it according 516
to this NW trend. The oblique cluster of kmin together with the kmax girdle plane in site MS4 indicate that magmatic flow 517
dips ~30° to SE, being parallel to the flat cooling joints observed in the field. Even with a small statistic number of 7 sites, 518
we can estimate that the silicic lavas flowed dominantly trending NW-SE or NE-SW. 519

4.2 Transport properties and implications on magma flow 524
4.2.1 Initial magmatic viscosity 525
The rheological properties of magma depend on temperature, bulk composition, pressure, phase assemblage, particle size 526
and shape distribution, spatial arrangement of particles (structure) and shear rate (Lesher & Sphera 2015). To complete the 527
interpretation of structural and magnetic fabric data we must consider the factors influencing the magma flow, so the 528
transport properties need to be constrained. In both conduits and lavas we used magmatic temperatures around 1000°C to 529
calculate viscosity. Values obtained are maximum dry viscosities ?max(dry) of ~ 6.6 log Pa s and minimum viscosities in more 530
hydrous conditions ?min(1.3H2O%) of ~ 3.8 log Pa s. 531
We confronted our data with the experimental investigation of Whittington et al. (2009), where rhyolitic and andesitic 532
magmas compositions are compared. For hydrous melts, at their respective magmatic temperatures, dacites and andesites 533
have similar viscosities. To quantify the importance of crystallinity effect on viscosity, we used the Einstein-Roscoe 534
equation (Einstein 1906, 1911; Roscoe 1952): ?r = ?mix/?melt = (1 - ?/ ?0) -2.5
, where ? is crystallinity in volume fraction, ?0 is 535
the maximum packing fraction (assumed as 0.6, value recommended for magmas in Marsh 1981) and ?r is the ratio of the 536
mixture (melt+crystals) viscosity, ?mix, to the melt viscosity, ?melt. The viscosity increases at ~19% for 5 vol.% of crystals, 537
used for the Mato Perso conduit and lavas. For Jaquirana vitrophyres we used 0.2 vol.%, which increased the viscosity 538
values in<1% (Fig. 15). With that we assume that low crystal content of the studied samples influenced irrelevantly for 539
raising up the magma viscosity. 540

547
The water content estimated for rhyodacites in Palmas-type magmas are around 2 wt.% (Garland et al. 1995) or, more 548
precisely, between 0.1 and 2.6 wt.% (Polo et al., 2017) and for the studied areas we are working with a maximum of 1.3 549
wt.%. This initial dissolved H2O value give a ?min that overlaps the andesite curve at 1050°C, indicating the similar initial 550
viscosities of the rhyodacites and andesitic melts, which is a favorable argument for their sheet-like geometry. 551
In terms of suspensions contained in the silicic magma, the key parameters controlling the rheological behavior of a bubble 552
suspension are the melt phase viscosity µ0, the capillary number Ca, the dynamic capillary number Cd and the relaxation 553
time (Mader et al. 2013). These variables depend on features that could not be experimentally measured, like bubble 554
relaxation time, shear strain rate and tension surface of the bubble-liquid interface. Even though, we observe that most parts 555
of the lava flows resemble monodisperse suspensions, because vesicles and amygdales range little in size and distribution. 556
Limited interaction between bubbles in these portions suggest relative steadiness (low Cd) in the flow. Shear strain rates or 557
the radius of spherical undeformed bubble (?) values should be large to contrast with the low µ0 and give high Ca. So we 558
expect flow regimes with both Ca and Cd controlled mainly by the initial liquid viscosity. 559
The central portion of the postulated conduits is similar in bubble content to the lava flows, but display much more stretched 560
vesicles. In the outer portions, where fragments reach more than 50% of vesicles, the viscosity and flow regime were 561
strongly dependent on the response of bubbles to shear rates. In these cases, strain shear rate, bubble relaxation and the 562
bubble content itself had an important control on viscosity, increasing the calculated initial liquid viscosity. 563
564
31
4.2.2 Flow domains and viscosity paths 565
In the path from margins to the core of conduits, the magma mixing structures and stretching of unconsolidated oxidized 566
vitrophyre fragments must also increase the viscosity of initial melts, but not as much as in the conduit margins, because the 567
fragments are less frequent. To the center of the flow, where we stablished ?max(dry) of ~ 6.6 log Pa s and ?min(1.3H2O%) of ~ 3.8 568
log Pa s, there is a domain where black obsidian is vertically structured, do not present fragments or mixing features. This 569
portion is where the magma could flow with more freedom at near-magmatic viscosity. The distribution of vesicles, 570
breccias and quartz veinlets in conduit systems is also horizontally profiled: more vesicles and breccias are features of the 571
outermost parts and scarce in the conduit cores. Quartz veinlets constitute discrete stockworks in the margins, while in the 572
center of the conduits the quartz veinlets are near-parallel to the magmatic flow (see Fig. 8d in detail). 573
In lavas, the absence of fragments and basal breccias in the sampled sites suggest that low viscosity suppressed the shear in 574
the base, and the high temperature inhibited the transition from ductile to fragile conditions impeding base of the flow to 575
break, such as in the base of some silicic lavas (e.g. Smith 1996; Tuffen et al. 2013) or basaltic/andesitic ‘a’a lavas (e.g. 576
Harris et al., 2017). Vesicles are heterogeneously disposed, having tube or spherical morphologies, but remaining at low 577
contents (up to 2%) throughout the main body of the lava flow. Quartz veinlets are almost absent, in exception of some 578
expositions with the development of flat-lying microfractured textures, which can be very late comparing with syn-579
emplacement structures. An important feature that should increase the melt viscosity in subaerial setting is the 580
crystallization of microlites in the groundmass (as in Figs. 10h and 11k). Even so, the crystallization of <2 vol.% of 581
clinopyroxene, Fe-Ti oxides and calcic plagioclase microlites must increase the relative water content in the magma, as 582
expected in retrograde boiling, thus keeping the viscosity at low values. 583
584
4.3 Tectonic setting and the emplacement of silicic lava in the southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP 585
Unraveling the plumbing system of silicic magmas in large igneous provinces is a still evolving matter, principally in the 586
Paraná-Etendeka LIP. Dyke swarms located within the Paraná Basin or intruding Precambrian crust in the Brazilian coast 587
are dominantly composed of mafic magma (basalt, andesi-basalt in composition). Silicic dykes are less common among the 588
intrusive terms. An example is in the Florianópolis dyke swarm, where they are described as ~ 70 - 80 m thick porphyritic 589
vitrophyre dykes trending NNE-SSW and NNW-SSE (Marteleto et al. 2015). Composite dykes with basaltic andesite 590
diabases mingled with rhyodacite also occur (Tomazzoli and Lima 2006). The intrusive silicic magmatism in the south of 591
the basin is represented by one occurrence of ~ 1 m thick rhyodacite dyke in the Praia Grande – Cambará do Sul profile 592
(Piccirillo et al. 1988). 593
The age of the silicic volcanism of ~134 Ma (Pinto et al. 2010; Janasi et al. 2011) and the position of these units in the top 594
of the volcanic pile are evidences that it was the final magmatic manifestations prior to the Gondwana break-up (Renne et 595
al., 1992, 1996; Turner et al., 1994; Bryan et al., 2002). This pre-rift setting (e.g. Stica et al. 2014) was ruled by extensional 596
tectonics (Hawkesworth et al. 1999), thermal influence of anomalously underlying mantle (Quintas et al. 1999; 597
Hawkesworth et al. 2000; Solomon et al. 2017) and reactivation of older Precambrian structures, which forms the shape of 598
the NE-SW coastline in south Brazil (see Figs 1, 2). Glen et al. (1997) obtained AMS data in 31 sites of basalt and diabase 599
in Namibia and 21 basalt flows in Brazil. Both flows and sills yielded magmatic flow directions (=kmax) to NE-SW and 600
32
minor to NW-SE, suggesting prevolcanic rifting, with magma flowing parallel to the rift. NW-SE and NE-SW trends are 601
also the main directions of mapped conduit occurrences, magmatic banding measured in the field and analyzed magnetic 602
fabric in silicic conduits and lavas (e.g. Canón-Tapia and Raposo 2017; Guimarães et al. 2017; Simões et al. 2017, this 603
study). This scenario of stretched crust with opening and closure of spaces in pre-existent faults is favorable for magmas 604
positioned in the mantle-crust boundaries to ascend and reach the surface. 605
The Paraná-Etendeka LIP was generated, at least in part, because the continental lithosphere had been thinned in response to 606
regional tectonics (Hawkesworth et al. 1999). High heat flux through the continental crust, generally associated with mantle 607
plumes, is a critical mechanism for voluminous melting (e.g. Condie 2001) maintaining high temperatures in open 608
magmatic reservoirs. In the other hand, mantle plumes may not be necessary for voluminous melting if it takes place in 609
specific extensional regimes (e.g. Foulger 2010; 2017). This type of storage system is way more effective in magma 610
transport than confined ones, where magma is kept stored in the crust for long times and reach high crystallization degrees 611
(Parfitt and Wilson, 2008). In a petrological point of view, the Palmas-type magmas derivate from low pressure 612
fractionation of low-Ti basalt magmas with some crust assimilation, increasing the Sr and Nd isotopic ratios (Peate et al. 613
1989; Garland et al. 1995) and were ponded at shallow depths, in pressure conditions inferior to 5 kbar (Garland et al. 1995; 614
Polo et al. 2017). The path between shallow crust and surface modelled as an extensional and pulsatory-fed system in which 615
the magma rises more easily through reactivation of fault zones attends well to the observed features, suggesting complex 616
ascending magma flow in the conduits. 617
The plumbing system, maintained in high temperatures, is the ideal source for these high-temperature silicic lava flows. A 618
constant source of mantle heat can keep fractionating basalt and andesite to form this hot silicic magma, inhibiting 619
crystallization and the association of OH - radicals to form hydrous minerals. This constant generation and rapid access to 620
the surface can explain the large volume of silicic magma in south Paraná-Etendeka LIP and also why the flows kept their 621
low viscosity and run so long to form extensive lava units (e.g. Hausback 1987; Henry et al. 1990; Henry and Wolff 1992; 622
Pankhurst et al. 2011; Tuffen et al. 2013), as the effect of high temperature also seen in extreme extensive lavas at Mercury 623
(e.g. Vetere et al. 2017), for example. 624
625
CONCLUSIONS 626
In the southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP, a large volume of silicic lava flows are the final stages of the Cretaceous volcanism 627
prior to the Gondwana break-up. We have described vitrophyre units comprised by brecciated, banded and folded 628
lithofacies, mapped as NW-SE to NE-SW trending structures and interpreted them as conduit systems. Measured banding in 629
the field also trends NW-SE and NE-SW, as the inferred magma flow directions obtained by AMS technique for conduits 630
and lavas. The distinction between conduits and lavas is found in both field structures, microscopic textures and in the 631
orientation of the magnetic fabric. Conduits have a greater dispersion of the AMS data and may have flat-lying or locally 632
vertical kmax, but the complexity of rheological behavior throughout the conduits have partitioned these systems in different 633
magma flow domains. In the lavas, horizontal kmax values coupled with horizontal magnetic foliations are a common pattern. 634
High-temperatures, low viscosity and water contents between 1 – 2 wt.% are explained by a constant high-temperature 635
storage system, linked to a reservoir ponded at the crust-mantle boundary through faults and are the reason why the silicic 636
magma did not explode, depositing as effusive lava flows. 637

Abstract 10
Low-Ti silicic volcanism of the Paraná-Etendeka large igneous province (LIP) is composed of flat-lying lavas 11
associated to the underlying flood basalts. Conduit-related and lava-related lithofacies architecture was previously 12
recognized in three study areas (from west to east: Mato Perso, MP; São Marcos, SM; and Jaquirana-Cambará do 13
Sul, JC). Silicic rocks are hemi-crystalline, containing<10% of plagioclase+pyroxene+Fe-Ti oxides+apatite±sanidine 14
phenocrysts and microlites. We present geochemical characterization, trace element modelling and estimations of 15
temperature, pressure, H2O content and viscosity, using mineral chemistry and whole-rock geochemical data. Mineral 16
compositions change from west to east, with calcic plagioclases and less ferric pyroxenes at MP and SM. JC have 17
sodic plagioclases plus sanidine, and more ferric pyroxenes. Whole-rock composition of metaluminous dacites display 18
fractional crystallization trend with the silicic glassy groundmass. Mass balance between basaltic andesite parental 19
magmas and dacites yielded good fits for 40-50% of fractionation using ~50% of plagioclase, 30-40% of 20
clinopyroxene, ~15-20% of titanomagnetite ±7-10% of sanidine. Silicic rocks have trace and rare earth element 21
patterns close to underlying basaltic andesites, being only slightly enriched. Assimilation plus fractional crystallization 22
modelling gave good fits at 20-40% of basalt andesite fractionantion and 20-80% peraluminous granites and 23
orthogneiss assimilation. Difference in trace element geochemical features, like Zr/Nb ratios are ascribed to variation 24
in mantle-derived sources and assimilants. Temperatures around ~950-1100°C dominate in the three areas, in both 25
plagioclase microphenocrysts and microlites, indicating high temperatures at emplacement. Water contents from 0.5-26
1.3 wt.%, decrease calculated viscosities from ~10 6 to 10
3 Pa s. Paleopressures for clinopyroxene crystallization are 27
compatible to a reservoir at the mantle-crust boundary. The magmatism evolution is explained by extensional 28
tectonics, where the necking of the continental crust decreased the distance between the reservoir and the surface, 29
causing progressively more efficient magma transport. Silicic magmas evolved from basaltic andesites, lost volatile 30
pressure within the conduits and erupted as lava flows. No pyroclastic material was massively ejected to the 31
atmosphere. The effusive character of silicic eruptions helped to avoid great climate changes and mass extinction in 32
Cretaceous. 33

Introduction 38
Large igneous provinces (LIPs) are dominated by thick, laterally extensive basaltic flows, sills, dykes and their 39
equivalent plutonic intrusions with some reaching volumes greater than 10 6
km 3 (e.g. Coffin and Eldholm, 1994; 40
Condie, 2001). The rapid and large extrusion of high-temperature magmas is proposed to be triggered in several 41
settings: mantle plumes (e.g. Condie, 2001; Campbell, 2005), crustal delamination and melting of dry eclogite 42
(e.g. Anderson, 2005), meteorite impacts (e.g. Jones, 2005) and distributed crustal extension (e.g. Foulguer, 43
2010, 2017). Major Phanerozoic LIPs have many differences regarding their eruptive products, stratigraphical 44
framework and even correlation with large mass extinction episodes (e.g. Jones et al., 2016). Almost of them 45
were erupted prior or during the Gondwana break-up, and some were developed during the extensional regimes 46
that led to the formation of the North, Central and South Atlantic Ocean (e.g. Buiter and Torsvik, 2014; Svensen 47
et al., 2017; Will and Frimmel, 2018). 48
In continental intraplate settings, upwelling mantle and decompression makes melting likely to occur (Wilson, 49
1989; Condie, 1997; Parfit and Wilson, 2008). The initial phases of volcanism generate picritic lavas in some 50
provinces, as registered in Afar, Deccan and Karoo (e.g. Krishnamurthy, 1977; Natali et al., 2011; Kamenetsky 51
et al., 2016) or may generate more primitive olivine-phyric basalts, as seen in the Paraná-Etendeka Province, 52
where they were emplaced as compound and ponded pahoehoe flows (Jerram et al., 1999; Barreto et al., 2014; 53
Rossetti et al., 2014, 2017). As seen in the Brazilian side of the Paraná-Etendeka LIP, the following products are 54
more evolved lavas as basaltic andesites, forming wide sheet pahoehoe and rubbly pahoehoe lava flow fields 55
(Waichel et al., 2012; Barreto et al., 2014; Rossetti et al., 2014; Rossetti et al., 2017). 56
Some LIPs display interleaved units of, or are covered by, silicic volcanic rocks (Eldholm et al., 1989; Sheth, 57
2007; Bryan and Ernst, 2008) which may reach >10 4 km³ in volume (Bryan et al., 2002), being formed mostly of 58
pyroclastic density current deposits and/or lava flows (Bryan et al., 2010). Silicic compositions from Phanerozoic 59
LIPs are similar in mineralogic composition, displaying dacitic to rhyolitic magmas with plagioclase, pyroxene, Ti-60
magnetite±ilmenite±sanidine±quartz and accessories as apatite±zircon±baddeleyite (Bellieni et al., 1984, 1986; 61
Comin-Chiaramonti, 1988, Garland et al., 1995, Muzio et al., 2009, Kirstein et al., 2000; Janasi et al., 2011; Ellis 62
et al., 2013; Natali et al., 2011; Sheth et al., 2012; Sheth and Pande, 2014). 63
The southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP comprises a thick sequence with ~1,200 m of exposed volcanic pile with 64
basalt-basaltic andesite lava fields overlain by a 15 x 10³ km² area of dominantly flat-lying silicic lava flows (e.g. 65
Henry and Wolf, 1992; Umann et al., 2001; Lima et al., 2012; 2018, Polo and Janasi, 2014; Simões et al., 2017), 66
locally displaying associated volcaniclastic and sedimentary volcanogenic sediments (Polo and Janasi., 2014; 67
Riccomini et al., 2015). Despite the source of silicic units in the southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP have been 68
proposed to be at the African counterpart of the LIP, travelling more than 300 km as pyroclastic density currents 69
(e.g. Milner et al., 1995; Bryan et al., 2010), studies of magnetic fabric using anisotropy of magnetic susceptibility 70
(AMS) in lava flows (e.g. Cañón-Tapia and Raposo, 2017, Guimarães et al., 2017) and the proposal of inferred 71
silicic feeder conduits for the overlying lava flows in Rio Grande do Sul state(e.g. Lima et al., 2018) re-opened 72
the discussion of the location of magma sources. The feeder conduits are exposed along 15-25 m in width 73
structures and expose processes of fragmentation, deformation and intrusion of oxidized and non-oxidized silicic 74
magma (Lima et al., 2012, 2018). The conduit zones are limited by faults dominantly trending NE- and NW-, 75
3
occurring south of the NE- trending Antas lineament, a structure that is parallel to the Precambrian basement 76
older structures. 77
In the present work we present a study in three areas of outcropping silicic lava flows and related feeder 78
conduits at northeast of Rio Grande do Sul, southern Brazil. In each area we selected samples to obtain a set of 79
mineral and whole-rock chemical analysis for geochemical characterization and geochemical modelling of open-80
system fractional crystallization and assimilation with fractional crystallization (AFC). A brief discussion about the 81
possible sources of silicic melts is given. Then we calculate transport properties (temperature, pressure, H2O 82
content and viscosity) and make a tectonic setting review to build a model of low-Ti silicic lava emplacement 83
during the early stages of Gondwana continental break-up. 84

1.1 Architecture of the southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP in South America 86
The Paraná-Etendeka LIP occupies an area of 917,000±15,000 km² (Frank et al., 2009) of which 90% is located 87
in South America and 10% is in Africa (Fig. 1a), being above the aeolian sedimentary rocks of Botucatu and Etjo 88
formations. In South America, the Paraná-Etendeka LIP comprises a 1700 m-thick association of tholeiitic 89
magmas (Melfi et al., 1988), with basaltic to intermediate lavas, dykes and sills prevalent (97.5% of total volume) 90
over silicic units (2.5%). 91
In a regional scale, the distribution of the Paraná-Etendeka LIP volcanic rocks is made by the classification of 92
mafic and silicic volcanics based in their TiO2 content (e.g. Bellieni et al. 1984; Peate et al. 1992). In the case of 93
the silicic rocks, the ones presenting high-Ti (TiO2>2 wt.%) are called Chapecó-type magmas (Peate et al. 94
1992): porphyritic trachytes with up to ~ 25 vol.% of crystals, exposed in the northern portion of the basin, 95
between the NW-SE trending Ponta Grossa arch and the Torres structural valley (Fig. 1b). In the southern 96
portion, where the studied areas outcrop, the low-Ti (TiO2<2 wt.%) rocks are dacites and rhyolites with less than 97
~10 vol.% of phenocrysts, called Palmas-type magmas. Parts of the plumbing system for basaltic and silicic low- 98
and high-Ti lavas in southern Brazil are represented by the NW-SE trending Ponta Grossa and the NE-SW 99
trending Santa Catarina and São Paulo dyke swarms (e.g. Raposo 1997; 1998, 2017; Florisbal et al. 2014). 100
South of the Torres valley, the volcanic units of southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP are represented by the Serra 101
Geral Group and, in southern Brazil, they cover the Aeolian strata of Botucatu Formation (Waichel et al., 2007) 102
and have chemically more primitive compound and simple pahoehoe basaltic flows in the base, represented by 103
the Torres Formation (Rossetti et al., 2017). Vertically stacked sheet-like rubbly pahoehoe basaltic flows of Vale 104
do Sol Formation cover the compound flows and represents the more voluminous basalt lava unit. The silicic 105
volcanics cover these basalt flows and are ascribed to the Palmas Formation. The last volcanic manifestations in 106
the area are the compound and simple oxidized basaltic flows of the Esmeralda Formation (Rossetti et al., 107
2017). 108
Silica saturated tholeiite and olivine tholeiite diabase dikes and sills occur striking NE-SE when cutting the 109
sedimentary units of Paraná basin and NW-SE when cutting the lava flows (Sarmento et al., 2017). The 110
postulated conduit systems for silicic lavas were described to the south of a curved NE- trending structure called 111
Antas Lineament. This structure is parallel to the main regional structures, like NE-SW trending Precambrian 112
4
Porto Alegre Suture (Fernandes et al., 1995) or younger faults cutting the basin as Leão and Açotea faults 113
(Zalán et al., 1991). 114
Further, towards the south of the LIP, a small area (3.2 km³) of peraluminous dacitic lavas with cordierite, 115
orthopyroxene, plagioclase and ilmenite as liquidus phases (Vieira 1985; Vieira and Roisenberg 1985) occurs in 116
the Jaguarão region. It contains abundant basement xenoliths and is located near to major shear zones of 117
Neoproterozoic age that may have been reactivated during Early Cretaceous (Comin-Chiaramonti et al., 2010). 118
In southern Uruguay, Mesozoic volcanics lie in a system of faulted basement blocks trending ~N60°E (Kirstein et 119
al. 2000). The silicic types are distinguished by two main groups of feldspar-phyric and quartz-phyric rocks 120
(Kirstein et al. 2000; 2001). Muzio et al. (2009) described lava flows and pyroclastic deposits of the Arequita 121
Formation, disposed along the N20°E India Muerta Lineament, an important tectonic control of the magmatic 122
evolution in Laguna Merín Basin. The mafic Santa Lucía type has OIB signatures with high Nb/La and Treinta Y 123
Trés is broadly similar to the low-Ti Gramado lavas (Kirstein et al. 2000). Felsic rocks are dacites to rhyolites 124
from Lavalleja Series (high Ti/Zr and Nb/Y, higher Sr and Nd isotope ratios) and Aigüa Series (high Rb/Sr, 125
Rb/Ba, and Th). 126

1.2 Lava geochemistry and age of silicic volcanics 134
Low-Ti and high-Ti silicic magma-types also display marked differences in trace element contents. High-Ti 135
volcanics are above high-Ti basalts or directly above the Aeolian sediments of Botucatu Formation (Janasi et al., 136
2007; 2011; Nardy et al., 2008; Luccheti et al., 2014) and have higher Ba, Nb, La, Ce, Zr (>500 ppm), P, Nd, Y, 137
Yb, Lu and K, being depleted in Rb, Th and U. Their isotopic composition display low ? 18
O values and 87
Sr/ 86
Sr(i) 138
between 0.705 and 0.708 (Peate et al. 1992; Peate 1997; Nardy et al. 2008). Palmas-type volcanics are divided 139
into Caxias do Sul (0.91%?TiO2?1.03%, 0.25%?P2O5?0.28%), Anita Garibaldi (1.06%?TiO2?1.25%, 140
0.32%?P2O5?0.36%) and Jacuí subtypes (1.05%?TiO2?1.16%, 0.28%?P2O5? 0.31%) and the rhyolites are 141
divided into Santa Maria (P2O5?0.21%) and Clevelândia (0.21%?P2O5?0.23%) subtypes (Peate et al., 1992; 142
Nardy et al., 2008), being characterized by low Zr (<400 ppm), high ? 18
O values and higher 87
Sr/ 86
Sr(i) values of 143
0.714-0.727 (e.g. Garland et al., 1995; Ewart et al., 2004). Crystal chemistry studies indicate dominance of more 144
sodic plagioclase as andesine in the high-Ti types, together with higher Ti contents in Fe-Ti oxides. Low-Ti lavas 145
have more calcic plagioclases (labradorite) and lower Ti in the oxides (Bellieni et al., 1988; Garland et al., 1995). 146
Polo et al. (2017) described plagioclases with An higher than 50 in Caxias do Sul and Barros Cassal dacites and 147
Santa Maria rhyolites. 148
Geochronological data and discussions presented by Thiede & Vasconcelos (2010) and Janasi et al. (2011) 149
suggest a cluster in ~134 Ma for the the high-Ti magmatism in central and northern Paraná Basin and also for 150
Gramado-type low-Ti basaltic flows and for the Esmeralda basaltic lavas, the uppermost unit of the Serra Geral 151
Group. The emplacement of volcanics of Paraná-Etendeka LIP and neighboring areas in Paraguay and 152
Argentina is consistent with a short duration of ~3 Ma for the building lava pile (Janasi et al. 2011). In the 153
Etendeka Province paleomagnetic studies recently suggested duration of ~4 Ma (Dodd et al., 2015). 154

1.3 Geomorphology and geological setting 156
The northeast portion of Rio Grande do Sul is the highest land of the state, reaching ~1,300 m above the sea 157
level (Fig. 2). From southwest to northeast, departing from the Jacuí river plain, the relief gradually reach 158
elevations of >1000 m through a horizontal distance of ~150 km. These highlands extend to Santa Catarina 159
state in the northeast direction, reaching ~1,700 m, and then the relief is gradually decreasing towards the 160
Atlantic Ocean. From southeast to northwest, departing from coast at the sea-level, we may reach 1,200 m of 161
elevation following a path of only ~30 km. These highlands gently decrease towards the plains of Paraná and 162
Paraguay rivers at west. The draw of the south Brazilian coast is along NE-trending structures, while more 163
subtle changes in relief are caused by NW-trending faults. Figure 2 localizes the study areas, namely, Mato 164
Perso, São Marcos and Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul in this context, and we add the information that the contact 165
between basaltic and silicic units in the LIP is at ~ 400m in Mato Perso, ~750 m in São Marcos and ~850 m in 166
Jaquirana and Cambará do Sul. 167
The geological reconnaissance of individual areas reveal banded vitrophyres and breccias from postulated silicic 168
conduits limited by NW and WNW-trending faults (Fig. 3a,b). Banded vitrophyres display steeply dips of 169
banding, grading laterally to more gently dips, and are composed of oxidized and non-oxidized vitrophyre bands 170
of centimeter to meter scale and present fragments with variate vesicle amounts and sizes (e.g. Lima et al., 171
6
2012; 2018; Simões et al., 2017). The Mato Perso area outcrops in high elevations at Farroupilha, Flores da 172
Cunha and Caxias do Sul cities. The highlands (>650 m) of Farroupilha and Caxias do Sul expose the felsic 173
conduit systems which are subtly demoted to ~400-550 m elevations by NE-trending normal faults through the 174
Antas River, where tabular vitrophyres are again in direct contact with basaltic rubbly pahoehoe flows. In Mato 175
Perso it was possible to map flat-lying oxidized lava units and dykes underlying flat-lying non-oxidized grey 176
vitrophyres (Fig. 3a). The inferred conduits cut these oxidized vitrophyres, carrying a lot of oxidized dragged out 177
fragments, and appear above the flat-lying grey vitrophyres, which in turn, may present red-grey banding on the 178
base of the flows (Simões et al., 2018, in press). In São Marcos and Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul these oxidized 179
lava units were not mapped (Fig. 3b,c), but the fragments are present within the inferred conduits. 180
Overall, the three areas share lithofacies architecture such as red vesicular, red poorly-vesicular, monomictic 181
and welded breccias in the margins and grey poorly vesicular and banded vitrophyres in the central parts 182
(Simões et al., 2017). The bands are dominantly subvertical (>60°) and thick (~10 cm), grading laterally into thin 183
(0,2 – 2 cm) flat-lying (<40°) banding marked by intercalation of 2- to 7- cm thick oxidized red colored bands and 184
grey colored bands. Monomictic breccias occurs in the border of the conduits, are banding-parallel and 185
composed of –mm to –cm scale angular vesicular oxidized red to brown fragments with sharp edges in seriate 186
arrangement cemented by calcite and silica. Spherulitic, microfractured, flay-lying coherent vitrophyres and flat-187
lying massive obsidian are the subaerial equivalents of the conduits. Flat-lying vitrophyres are ~ 5 - 20 m thick 188
units with at least 10 km² in area and show flat-lying foliation, pipe vesicles in the base, and spheroidal vesicles 189
towards the top of the unit, locally presenting basal breccia. 190

2 Methods 200
Detailed description of outcrops and field relations at the investigated areas are presented by Simões et al. 201
(2017, 2018, in press). After the field works, 34 samples were selected for petrographic descriptions and 11 thin 202
sections (01 lava flow, 01 conduit-vitrophyre of Mato Perso; 02 microfractured, 02 spherulitic and 02 banded 203
vitrophyres from Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul, 01 banded vitrophyre from São Marcos and 02 lava-flow samples 204
from Cambará do Sul) were polished with diamond paste to use on Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) 205
coupled with Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) and obtain high resolution images and chemical element 206
maps. Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) analyses were made in a LS15 Zeiss microscope in the Geological 207
Survey of Brazil-CPRM laboratory of Belém. A high-vacuum mode (3.0 – 1.5 10 -5
mPa) and a tungsten filament 208
were used. A 10 ?m-thick gold pellicle was utilized to cover the polished sections. Backscattered electron 209
images were obtained with 20 kV, current between 70 and 90 pA, work distance of 8.5 mm and 100 to 500 times 210
magnification. Chemical maps of the sections were obtained by Energy Dispersive Spectrometry in an Oxford 211
Instruments X-Act SSD 10mm 2
detector. Analytical results were obtained with counting rate of 2000 cps and 212
standardized by energy spectrum patterns from the AZTec (Oxford Instruments) program. 213
The same thin sections were used for major oxides quantification in plagioclase, sanidine, clinopyroxene, Fe-Ti 214
oxides and glassy matrix using Electron Probe Micro Analyzer (EPMA). EPMA analyses were carried out in the 215
University of Brasília (UnB) in a JEOL JXA-8230 microanalyzer model with five WD (wavelength dispersive) and 216
8
one ED (electron dispersive) spectrometers. The mineral analyses were made with 15 kV current, 20 nA of 217
acaleration and spot diameter between 5 and 10 micrometers. To avoid the diffusion of elements such Na and K 218
in glass analyses, the currents were reduced to 10 nA and the beam was defocused to 15 to 20 micrometer 219
diameter. 220
The whole-rock composition of 34 volcanic felsic rock samples was determined for comparison between different 221
sites of conduit systems occurrence and between distinct lithofacies. The whole rock chemical analyses were 222
made at Acme Analytical Laboratories Ltd., in Vancouver, Canada, using analysis routines 4A and 4B. In the 223
former, total abundance of main oxides and several minor elements was obtained from 0.2 g of the analyzed 224
sample by Inductively Coupled Plasma — Emission Spectrometry (ICP-ES) with the detection limit of 0.01% for 225
SiO2, Al2O3, Fe2O3, CaO, MgO, Na2O, K2O, MnO, TiO2 and P2O5. In the second one, the results of rare earth 226
and refractory element were obtained from 0.2 g of analyzed sample by ICP – MS (Mass Spectrometry) with 227
detection limit of 1 ppm for Ba, Be and Sn, 0.1 ppm for Ce, Cs, Hf, La, Nb, Rb, Ta, U, Y and Zr, 0.2 ppm for Co 228
and Th, 0.3 ppm for Nd and 0.01-0.05 ppm for Dy, Er, Eu, Gd, Ho, Lu, Pr, Sm, Tb, Tm and Yb. 229

3 Results 231
3.1 Mineral and glassy groundmass chemistry 232
Vitrophyre mineralogy is composed of plagioclase (minor sanidine), clinopyroxene and Fe-Ti oxides as 233
phenocrysts and microphenocrysts immersed in a microlite-rich hemi-crystalline groundmass made by the same 234
mineral assemblage plus apatite. The totality of samples share general features such plagioclase and pyroxene 235
microphenocrysts altered to clay minerals, more frequently in their core; in lavas the microphenocrysts have no 236
preferred orientation but conduit microphenocrysts can be oriented according to the banding. Lava flow units 237
have far more shape/size developed microlites than banded vitrophyres of inferred conduits. The main textural 238
differences between the three areas are phenocryst and microphenocryst content (plagioclase, clinopyroxene, 239
Fe-Ti oxides±sanidine), decreasing from Mato Perso (<10%) to São Marcos (<2%) and Jaquirana-Cambará do 240
Sul (<1%). Clinopyroxene contents also decrease from Mato Perso and São Marcos to Jaquirana-Cambará do 241
Sul. Microphenocryst size hierarchy is verified in feldspar, pyoxenes and Fe-Ti oxides ranging from larger 242
crystals in Mato Perso to smaller crystals in São Marcos and even smaller crystals in Jaquirana-Cambará area. 243
Mineral chemistry was carried out in feldspars, pyroxenes and Fe-Ti oxides using representative samples from 244
each studied area. For each mineral group we realized ±90 spots, presented in appendix A. The characteristics 245
of each mineral group in the studied areas are present in table 1. In Mato Perso area, due to the larger size of 246
the crystals, there was the possibility to compare the chemistry of microlites and microphenocrysts (core, 247
intermediate region and rims, figure 4). However, the very fine-grained microlites from São Marcos and 248
Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul could not be analyzed because their size is smaller than the EPMA spot size, so 249
these crystals would not give reliable data, some grains are reported as ‘whole-grain’ because the spot area was 250
near the size of the entire minerals. 251

3.1.1 Feldspars 257
The main feldspars in the analyzed samples are plagioclases with minor volume of sanidine, the second only 258
occurring in Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul area. The distinctive features between the study areas are in size, shape 259
and composition of plagioclases. Complete average compositions for feldspars in each area are present in table 260
2. In Mato Perso area, the microphenocrysts from both lavas (Fig. 5a) and conduits (Fig. 5b) are subhedral to 261
euhedral. Lavas have subhedral microlites with ~0.2 mm in size, locally with sieve texture or as empty or 262
skeleton crystals (Fig. 5c). In São Marcos the microphenocrysts have more subhedral and anhedral shapes, 263
sometimes presenting resorbing textures. A notable feature of lava flow samples near the conduit is the variety 264

3.1.4 Aggregates 328
Several types of microphenocryst aggregates occur in both conduits and lavas. The most common types show 329
globular clinopyroxene crystals involving one or two plagioclase laths (Fig. 7a), locally with the plagioclase ‘c’ 330
axis oriented according to the banding, or populations of 4-6 plagioclase crystals involving globular Fe-Ti oxides. 331
A more rare kind of aggregate is similar to those described by Ellis et al. (2012) at the Snake River ignimbrites 332
and is composed of 5-10 subhedral clinopyroxene and plagioclase crystals. One of these aggregates in a 333
banded vitrophyre sample from Mato Perso contains subhedral to anhedral prisms of augite enveloping a silica-334
rich groundmass. The augites presented very similar composition, with the enstatite component only variying 335
between Ens35 and Ens36. A plagioclase crystal, also part of the aggregate display homogeneous composition, 336
with An52, from the core to the rims (Fig.7b). 337
