3.1.5 Glassy groundmass 339
Despite the average of ~ 1-5% for microphenocryst contents in the silicic vitrophyres, there is a slightly 340
difference in microlite/glassy groundmass proportions. However, this difference is accented when comparing 341
conduit and lava flow-related lithofacies. Banded vitrophyres may be almost holohyaline, with few 342
microphenocrysts parallel to the banding. In general the mm-scale bands are marked by hematite-rich and 343
hematite-poor zones, which are cross-cut by en-echelon quartz veinlets (Fig. 8a). Variation in hematite content 344
is responsible by the different response of the vitrophyres to abrasion, making the hematite-rich zones very 345
difficult to be well-polished (right portion of figure 8b), contrasting with hematite-poor zones, characterized to be 346
enriched in microcrystalline quartz, giving well-polished surfaces (left portion of figure 8b). In the lava flow units, 347
which are commonly isotropic, the glassy groundmass volume constitutes approximately 50-70% of the 348
vitrophyres and it is separated into hematite-rich and hematite-poor patches. These patches may be silica-rich, 349
white colored in plane-polarized light under the microscope, or hematite-rich, brown colored. This brown colored 350
glass has a plumose texture with several perlitic fractures in larger or thinner lengths (Fig. 8c, d). Hematite-rich 351
zones in both conduits and lavas are very difficult to be polished and the EPMA analyses rarely give 352
15
considerable results. Thus, we realized most of our analyses in the hematite-poor bands and patches to 353
characterize their chemical composition. 354

3.2.2.1 Model of open-system fractional crystallization 494
Despite that fractional crystallization models have alredy been tested for silicic melts in the Paraná-Etendeka LIP 495
(e.g. Bellieni et al., 1986; Piccirilo et al., 1988; Garland et al., 1995; Ewart et al., 2004), we applied a different 496
approach using an open-magma chamber model from O’Hara (1977) in an excel spreadsheet (Appendix D). 497
This model simulates a high-level magma chamber being periodically fed by batches of parental magma. Mixed 498
23
magmas undergo continuous fractional crystallization, leaving a mass fraction of a cumulate (X), a mass fraction 499
of the original liquid before fractionation (Y) extracted as a lava flow in each cycle and a mass of parental 500
magma added in each cycle (Z). For this, we selected four samples of Gramado-type andesi-basalts Lima et al. 501
(2012) and used their average (Table 6) as parental magma. 502
The rhyodacites display ~3 to ~5 times more Rb, U and K than the chosen parental magma, with the rest of the 503
elements being 1.5-3 times greater. To run the model we used a solid assemblage with plagioclase (49%), 504
clinopyroxene (35%), K-feldspar (2%), magnetite (10%), ilmenite (3,5%) and apatite (0.5%). Partition coefficients 505
(Kd) were compiled from Schnetzler and Philpotts (1970), Leeman (1979), Leeman and Felps (1981), Nash and 506
Crecraft (1985), Bacon and Druitt (1988), Sisson (1991), Rollinson (1993), Stimac and Hickmott (1994) and 507
Ewart and Griffin (1994). The concentration of the elements in the erupted lava (CB s ) fits with the composition of 508
our silicic samples in a range of 40-90% of cumulate left (X) for Ba, Sr, Zr, Rb, Nb, Ta, Th, Hf, and Pb. 509
Concentrations of Eu, Yb and Lu were achieved only with >90% of X (Fig. 14). 510

3.3 Intensive Parameters 555
3.3.1 Apatite saturation thermometry 556
Apatite saturation temperatures were calculated following the model of Harrison & Watson (1984) taking account 557
that the model is limited by diffusion of phosphorous in the melt and apatite is a common accessory mineral in 558
the studied vitrophyres. To calculate the variable lnD (P2O5apatite/P2O5melt), the whole rock P2O5 content was used 559
and the phosphorous partition coefficient was considered as 42 (Prowatke & Klemme, 2006). Calculated 560
temperatures range from 1015-1073°C in Mato Perso samples, 1059-1112°C in São Marcos and 1005-1109°C 561
in Jaquirana Cambará. The temperatures should represent the temperature of apatite saturation in the melt. 562
Since apatites are microlites in the groundmass or inclusions in feldspars, those temperatures are good 563
estimates for the magma liquidus. 564
565

requires inputs of mineral chemistry data of plagioclase microphenocrysts and microlites achieving equilibrium 568
with a melt, which we chose as whole-rock and glass compositions. As the temperature is pressure-dependent, 569
the constant pressure utilized was 0.1 kbar. 570

4 Discussion 633
4.1 Textural and compositional variations in the studied areas 634
Despite very similar in major element composition, the vitrophyres outcropping in the study areas differ in 635
petrographic features, like microphenocryst content from west to east: Mato Perso, ~5-10%; São Marcos, ~<2%; 636
Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul,<1% - and decrease in volume of pyroxene microphenocrysts, also in this direction. 637
Microprobe data presented in this study reveal that the anorthite content of plagioclase decreases in this 638
geographical trend, together with the slightly enrichment of ferrossilite component in augite. Titanium contents in 639
Ti-magnetite and in pyroxenes largely overlap between the three areas, as well as their glassy matrix 640
composition. 641
Plagioclase composition is controlled by temperature, melt composition and melt H2O content (e.g. Humphreys 642
et al., 2016). In anhydrous melts, the plagioclase composition in equilibrium shifts systematically toward albite 643
with decreasing temperature (e.g. Bowen, 1913; Kudo and Weill, 1970; Drake, 1976). In hydrous melts, the 644
shape of the albite-anorthite binary loop in T-X space is broadened and shifted to lower temperature relative to 645
anhydrous compositions (Kudo and Weill, 1970; Drake, 1976; Johannes, 1984). In our samples the calculated 646
temperatures using both whole-rock and plagioclase thermometers are very close (Table 6), suggesting a major 647
role of the dissolved water content variation in the magma as controller of plagioclase compositions. The 648
prevalence of larger and more calcic plagioclase crystals in Mato Perso suggests lower dissolved H2O contents 649
in the melt than the other two areas. In São Marcos, plagioclase compositions are also calcic, but the crystals 650
tend to be smaller, probable by variation in undercooling degree. In the whole Paraná-Etendeka LIP the 651
29
plagioclase solid-solution has distinguished high-Ti silicic magma-types, with compositions up to An50, from low-652
Ti magma-types, displaying more calcic compositions up to An70 (Bellieni et al., 1984; 1986; Garland et al. 1995; 653
Ewart et al., 2004). Calcic plagioclase composition has also been found in Caxias do Sul dacites of Polo et al. 654
(2017). The results obtained at Jaquirana-Cambará area indicate that Palmas-type/Caxias do Sul sub-type 655
magmas can also have more sodic plagioclase assembly and tend to present associated sanidine 656
microphenocrysts. 657
Fe-Ti oxide compositions suggest that fO2 conditions affected only the linear variation of T Fe

The presence of aggregates with plagioclase and clinopyroxene displaying very close compositions has been 662

reflect a magmatic system in which the magma was physically segregated into a number of separate bodies 664
evolving in parallel prior to eruption (Ellis et al., 2012). 665
In terms of major element whole-rock composition, the analyzed samples do not vary systematically. This is also 666
valid when comparing the investigated areas or the different textural and color types. Despite several textures 667
involving magma mixing patterns, such as polyclinal folds with several folding phases (e.g. Perugini and Poli, 668
2012) occur in the study areas, this chemical similarity is a favorable argument to postulate there was no mixing 669
of magmas with accented chemical distinction. Although Na loss during devitrification is a common process in 670
Caxias do Sul volcanics (e.g. Andrade et al., 2017), the glass compositions do not variate from one area to 671
another and follow the path of fractional crystallization, increasing the alkalis content of the glass and giving well-672
fit mass balance at the same mineral proportions as microlite contents observed at thin sections. 673
In the case of trace element variations, the more pronounced features are the Zr/Nb ratios, which are lower in 674
São Marcos and higher in Mato Perso and Jaquirana-Cambará. The work of Kirstein et al. (2001) in silicic 675
volcanics from Uruguay suggest the Zr and Nb contents being controlled by the presence of halogens as F - and 676
Cl - . For them, high Zr/Nb ratios are proportional to high-fluorine content and rocks with high Zr/Nb ratios 677
emplaced effusively. Further, low Zr/Nb ratios in the Palmas and Lavalleja magma-types would be a chemical 678
explanation for their explosive emplacement. We argue firstly that Zr/Nb ratios are not indicative of magma 679
explosivity, and secondly that the majority of Palmas-type volcanic deposits is effusive in origin, not explosive. 680
Zr and Nb have very different bulk composition coefficients in an upper-mantle melting regime, expressed as 681
DZr solid/liquid
>> DNb solid/liquid
(e.g. Green et al., 1989) and the linearity patterns between these two elements cannot 682
be explained only by fractional crystallization. In OIB magmas the Zr vs Nb concentration arrays must reflect 683
intra-mantle processes like carbonatitic fluid metassomatism or carbonate-silicate immiscibility (Kamber and 684
Collerson, 2000). A sample of basaltic-andesite collected in Mato Perso gave Zr/Nb ratio of 13.6, similar to those 685
found in the rhyodacites. Comparing to the basaltic andesite chemical data of Lima et al. (2012), in São Marcos 686
the Zr/Nb ratios are about 11-12 in samples from pahoehoe and rubbly pahoehoe flows. Chemical data from the 687
Bom Princípio-Caxias do Sul profile (from Rossetti et al., 2014) yielded Zr/Nb ratios of ~13-14 for compound 688
pahoehoe at the base, ~10-13 for simple and pounded pahoehe, and ~11-15 for rubbly pahoehoe flows. In the 689
Santa Cruz do Sul – Herveiras profile, the values lie on 9-18 for pahoehoe (pounded and compound) and 13-15 690
30
for rubbly pahoehoe. This marked variation in Zr/Nb ratios between stratigraphic units within the province is 691
thought to be caused by two possible processes acting together: one is the variation in mantle Zr-Nb 692
composition in a large scale (50-150 km) and the other is the assimilation of the underlying basement with 693
various Zr/Nb ratios in a minor scale (5-50 km), for example at different granitic bodies and gneiss complexes. 694
Our model of AFC reached a good fit for Zr-Nb with 40% of assimilation of peraluminous granite and 80% of 695
fractionation, for example, but a lot of sources could be included in a complex process of assimilation because of 696
the horizontal and vertical lithological variation into the continental crust. 697
698
4.2 Origin of low-Ti silicic melts and implications for eruption 699
Far more complete petrogenetic studies for Paraná-Etendeka low-Ti silicic melts were developed, for example, 700
by Mantovani et al. (1985), Garland et al. (1995), Peate (1997) and Ewart et al. (2004). In general, crystal 701
fractionation of low-Ti Gramado magma-types associated to the assimilation of continental crust is a model that 702
efficiently explains the major, trace element and isotopic composition of the silicic rocks. Although melting of 703
mafic basement or underplated low-Ti basalts is too advocated (e.g. Bellieni et al., 1986; Harris et al. 1990; 704
Harris and Milner, 1997). Kilpatrick and Ellis (1992) found the chemical composition of the Paraná-Etendeka 705
silicic volcanics very close to igneous charnockites generated by high-temperature crustal melting, suggesting 706
they are not related to the spatially associated flood basalts. Indeed, trace elements, Sr-Nd isotopic 707
compositions of both silicic and mafic magmas are only explained by vast array of crustal contamination 708
(Garland et al., 1995; Ewart et al., 2004; Barreto et al., 2016). In addition, oxygen isotopic compositions are only 709
explained if the low-Ti silicic magmas are considered approximately pure crustal melts (Harris et al., 1990; Harris 710
and Milner, 1997). 711
As confirmed in this study by mass balance and AFC modelling, Palmas-type magma compositions deriving 712
from underlying low-Ti basalts and basaltic andesites generally yield at a good fit at 40-60% of fractionation and 713
20% of basement assimilation (e.g. Garland et al., 1995). The resemblance of trace and rare earth elements 714
behavior of Vale do Sol Formation rubbly pahoehoe basaltic andesites and the low-Ti volcanics is another 715
argument for their conjugate evolution (see Fig 13). Similar fractionation-assimilation proportions were also 716
observed for basaltic andesites fractionation from underlying more primitive basalts. Geochemical models 717
supported by Sm-Nd isotopic studies reveal they also need several distinct proportions of Paleoproterozoic to 718
Neoproterozoic mafic and felsic assimilation (e.g. Barreto et al., 2016). Even though, participation of open-719
system like processes during fractionation is not discarded. Another important geochemical feature to consider 720
in the petrogenesis is that plagioclase, pyroxenes and Fe-Ti oxide compositions overlap their parent basalt and 721
basalt andesite (e.g. Bellieni et al., 1984; Bellieni et al., 1988; Garland et al., 1995). 722
Based on this and in the fractional crystallization models for underlying compound, ponded and rubbly 723
pahoehoe, we explain the origin of the silicic low-Ti melts from large-scale crystal fractionation of their 724
precursors in the lava pile and assimilation of basement rocks with a wide range of age and chemical/isotopic 725
compositions, as already pointed out by Peate (1997), Garland (1995) and Ewart (1994). Melting of underplated 726
dry eclogite, as proposed by Anderson (2005) for LIP formation, is not discarded to act together with melting of 727
31
the upper mantle near the base of the crust because of the lower eclogite solidus (~1200°C at 2MPa), compared 728
to lherzolite (~1400°C at 2MPa). 729
730
4.3 Tectonic setting during lava eruption 731
According Philipp et al. (2016), the Proterozoic basement exposed in southern Brazil is composed, from east to 732
west, of: (1) a granitic belt with few basement remnants (Pelotas Batolith, Neoproterozoic), (2) 733
Metassedimentary units with minor metagranitoids and orthogneisses (Tijucas Belt, Paleo-Neoproterozoic); (3) 734
tonalite-granite-granodiorite and metaultramafic sequences of arc setting (São Gabriel Terrane, Neoproterozoic) 735
and (4) Mafic and felsic granulites from Taquarembó Terrane (Paleoprotrozoic). The contacts between terranes 736
are dominantly by NE-SW major shear zones as Dorsal de Canguçu and Passo dos Marinheiros besides the 737
NW-trending Ibaré (e.g. Picada, 1971; Fernandes et al., 1995; Chemale Jr, 2000; Philipp et al., 2016). Following 738
the main Neoproterozoic orogenic events, the cratonization of western Gondwana, in the beginning of Cambrian, 739
was marked by crustal displacements at NE-trending transcurrent shear zones, opening spaces for marine, 740
fluviatile and aeolian sediment deposition accompanied by shoshonitic to alkaline magmatism within the 741
Camaquã Basin (Lima & Nardi, 1998; Bitencourt & Nardi, 2000; Chemale Jr., 2000; Hartmann et al., 2007; 742
Philipp et al. 2016). 743
After the post-collisional tectonic stabilization, the intracratonic sedimentation of the Paraná Basin (e.g. Allen and 744
Armitage, 2012) started in the Ordovician. The geodynamic within the active margin of Gondwana influenced the 745
Paleozoic and Mesozoic evolution of the basin. Integrated analysis of the basin subsidence confronted to great 746
orogenic episodes in the continental margin revealed relation between them and the depositional space creation 747
cycles (Milani et al., 2007). Zalán et al. (1990) interpret the thermal contraction succeeding tectonomagmatic 748
events during the Brasiliano Cycle as an important mechanism for the syneclise implantation. The thermo-749
mechanical model of Quintas et al. (1999) indicate that major tectonic subsidence epidodes occurred during 750
Permian, with a mean value of 50 m/My, growing in time from the deposition of Palermo Formation (30m/My) to 751
the deposition of Rio do Rasto Formation (92m/My). Triassic sequences of southern Paraná Basin were 752
developed during reactivation of NW-SE structures, later again reactivated in the Cretaceous as normal faults by 753
NE-trending extension (Zerfass et al., 2005). During Cretaceous, after a long period of marine followed by 754
continental sedimentation, there was a peak of the Andine chain uplifting (e.g. Karl et al., 2013) in the west 755
board of Gondwana, while continental crust extension accompanied by voluminous basaltic and silicic volcanism 756
dominated within the continent forming the Paraná-Etendeka LIP. 757
Several works regarding the origin of the Paraná-Etendeka LIP enormous hot magma output ascribed its 758
genesis to the action of a mantle plume, generally related to the Tristan da Cunha hot spot (e.g. Hawkesworth et 759
al., 1992; Peate, 1997; Condie, 2001; Campbell, 2005; Gibson et al., 2006; Natali et al., 2018). Usually the 760
authors assume the work of the plume leading to continental stretching and consequent break-up (e.g. Gallagher 761
and Hawkesworth, 1994) with the magma intrusion following reactivation of older faults (e.g. Valente et al., 762
2007). On the other hand, seismic-tomographic investigations have pointed out to a minor role of mantle plume 763
(e.g. Fromm et al., 2015) and magnetotelluric data interpretation propose the absence of a plume structure 764
under the Tristan da Cunha island (Baba et al., 2016). Geochemical evidence is also recently putting in doubt 765
32
the role of mantle plumes in the generation of high-Ti melts from the northern portion of the Paraná-Etendeka 766
LIP (Rocha-Júnior et al., 2012, 2013), and for basalts from Central Atlantic and also Ferrar provinces (e.g. Hole, 767
2015), for example. 768
Anisotropy of magnetic susceptibility (AMS) studies developed in dyke swarms (e.g. Raposo, 2017; Wiegand et 769
al., 2011), in silicic lava flows and conduits (Cañón-Tapia and Raposo, 2017; Guimarães et al., 2017) indicate 770
preferred NE-SW and NW-SE trends for magma flow, parallel to the dyke strikes. This is in agreement with the 771
AMS study of Glenn et al. (1997), in dykes and lava flows in the both Brazilian and Namibian sides of the LIP, 772
also presenting dominant NE-SW trending of the magnetic fabric, suggesting lava flow emplacement during a 773
rifting phase. Rifting chronology of interpreted seismic sections positioned parallel to the Torres valley made by 774
Stica et al. (2014) affirm the deposition of the Paraná-Etendeka volcanics only in a pre-rift stage, minimizing the 775
effects of the province being causative of West Gondwana rupture and break-up. Although paleomagnetic data 776
interpretation of Collier et al. (2017) point out the Paraná-Etendeka volcanics as coeval to linear anomalies 777
present in the oceanic crust at South Altantic off-shore. 778
McKenzie and Bickle (1988) demonstrated that, the amount of melt generated in basins with associated 779
volcanism depends on the potential temperature of the asthenosphere and the amount of extension. It is given 780
that normal asthenosphere temperatures are ~1280°C, and the additional temperature of 100°C would be 781
needed to generated 2 km of melt in a 100 km-thick lithosphere stretched by a factor of 2 (Allen and Allen, 782
2009). The reconstruction model of Foulguer (2017) for the province at 134 Ma requires ~150 km of dextral slip 783
and ~70 km of extension between Santos and Rio de La Plata blocks, and proposing the magmatism would be 784
formed by rifting spread as in the North Atlantic Province. These recent models of Foulguer (2010, 2017) explain 785
elegantly how tectonic stretching, as response for an orogenic event in the craton margin, can be responsible for 786
mantle upwelling confined to the upper mantle, thus not restricting heat anomalies to the lower mantle. 787
788
4.4 Storage, magma transport and emplacement conditions 789
Mineral chemistry of pyroxene crystals in this study and equilibrium tests between pyroxenes and liquid present 790
in Polo et al. (2017) suggest pressures of formation (~1.5-9 kbar) equivalent to depths of ~10-30 km for this 791
phase in low-Ti silicic rocks. As postulated by Bellieni et al. (1988), the Mg content of pyroxenes from silicic 792
volcanics is relatively high and the pyroxene compositions plot essentially in the same fields corresponding to 793
pyroxenes from the andesi-basalts and andesite, so the same depth of formation can be inferred to mafic melts. 794
This depth represents, like demonstrated in the model of Molina et al. (1988), for example, the position of a 795
reservoir ponded in the mantle-crust boundary. 796
Figure 16a presents a sketch with the model of transport from this source. The magma crosses the crust 797
facilitated by tectonic movements during crustal necking and migrates through the opening of spaces into the 798
transcrustal basement faults, and then through major basin faults. Progressive stretching of continental crust 799
started with accommodation of the major blocks and reactivation of the Neoproterozoic and basin faults (Fig. 800
16a-i). Primitive olivine-phyric basalts from Torres Formation are generated by mantle melting driven by 801
decompression and increasing mantle temperatures (Fig. 16a-ii). The reservoir is kept in high temperature, then 802
higher melting degrees, fractional crystallization plus constant assimilation of the base of continental crust 803
33
generated thick basaltic-andesite units from Vale do Sol Formation in few thousands, or at maximum ~1-2 Ma 804
(Fig. 16a-iii). After a period of huge Fe-Ti oxide crystallization in mafic magmas, silicic melts become more 805
stable (e.g. Melfi et al., 1988; Peate, 1997) and the magma continue erupting from faults trending NE-/NW- (Fig. 806
16a-iv), fractionating and assimilating country-rocks (Fig. 16a-v, b). This high-temperature silicic magma 807
ascended through paths, from the reservoir to the surface, which became shorter and shorter due to progressive 808
stretching. The following scenario is the continental break-up and generation of oceanic crust, with rift phase 809
dominated by magma-rich passive margin basins. Figure 16a-v is a compilation of recent seismic data 810
interpretation made by Stica et al. (2014) in the coast of Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil) and Bauer et al. (2000) in the 811
Cape Cross transect (Namibia), with oceanic crust minimized in the cartoon, showing that actual margins have 812
possible zones of underplating. 813
Considering the fine textures in mafic and silicic volcanics, it is evident that there was a very short time for 814
crystals to grow. In addition to that, another latent fact is the short time for the emplacement of the entire 815
Paraná-Etendeka LIP magmatism. In southeast and southern Brazil, it have been estimated to be in ~ 3 Ma (e.g. 816
Janasi et al., 2011), and in Namibia it is estimated to last ~4 Ma (e.g. Dodd et al., 2015). These arguments imply 817
that a plumbing system remained connected and constantly draining the subaerial eruptions, until the final silicic 818
manifestation. 819
Besides high eruptive temperatures >1000°C, another consensus in literature is the low dissolved water 820
contents (<2 wt.%) for silicic volcanics in the LIP (e.g. Garland et al., 1995; Polo et al., 2017; this study). This is 821
in agreement with the absence of magmatic hydrous phases such as amphibole. The ascending magma with 822
low dissolved water contents taken place in a progressive extensional regime makes the existent gas to scape 823
very efficiently (e.g. Cashman, 2004, Fig. 16c). In subsurface, shallow conduits of magma were tectonically 824
controlled, and the paths of volatile loss described in inferred conduits such as brecciation, welding and 825
fracturing (Fig. 16d1) prevented explosive eruptions (Lima et al., 2012; Simões et al., 2017; Lima et al., 2018). 826
The lavas present closed-system vesicle architecture paths (Simões et al., 2018, in press), since there was no 827
development of an upper breccia carapace (Fig. 16d2). Field and AMS data obtained in sites at São Marcos and 828
Gramado Xavier regions have pointed out to the presence of channelized flows (e.g. Canõn-Tapia and Raposo, 829
2017; Guimarães et al., 2017). Plagioclase-liquid temperatures estimated from the chemistry of microlites, 830
present only in lava flows, yielded temperatures of ~ 950°C, suggesting that the lava body kept the high 831
temperature conditions during emplacement. 832
In our samples, the water dissolved in the magma, with contents up to ~ 0.5-1.3 wt.%, is favorable to decrease 833
viscosity to values of ~ 10 3.5
Pa s, being a key factor to keep the flow running to long distances. Considering 834
closed-system lavas with well-insulated carapaces (c.f. Harris and Rowland, 2009), for example, these silicic 835
flows may attain even greater distances than expected for these viscosities. The crystallization of anhydrous 836
microlite assemblage should increase the relative water content of the lavas during emplacement, thus 837
decreasing viscosity even more. As anorther example of low viscosity lavas, values near 10 3.5
Pa s were also 838
suggested to the emplacement of >100 km in length silicic lobate flows of the Gawler Range Silicic LIP, making 839
these silicic sequences geometrically similar to the basaltic provinces. In their specific case, the A-type 840
geochemical affinity of the lavas and consequent high fluorine content was the more relevant geochemical 841
feature to decrease the lava viscosity (Agangi et al., 2011; Pankhurst et al., 2011). 842

The most known cases of large-volume silicic volcanism, is ascribed to plinian eruptions and large amounts of 856
ignimbrite succeeded by emplacement of small-volume coulées or domes (Branney et al., 2008), being capable 857
of regional obliteration and climatic perturbation (e.g. Sparks et al., 2005). In the case of LIPs, global 858
environment may be impacted by eruptive release of gas and aerosols like SO2, CO2 and halogens (Saunders, 859
2005; Self, 2005). The role of silicic volcanism in this theme has been brought to explain the end-Guadalupian 860
mass extinction in the Emeishan LIP, where silicic pyroclastic beds are thought to participate in the climate 861
changes (e.g. Xu et al., 2016). On contrary of Emeishan, Central Atlantic, and Deccan provinces, the Brazilian 862
side of Paraná-Etendeka LIP does not correlate with great mass extinctions. Although investigation of SO2, CO2, 863
CH4, F and Cl mass fluxes for mafic and silicic volcanics are not available yet, we argue the effusive behavior of 864
35
the silicic eruptions can minimize climate impact, if compared with dominant explosive eruptions, avoiding large 865
amount of particles rise up in an eruptive column, reach the stratosphere and disperse. 866
Conclusions 867
Large-volume lavas were the prevalent deposit of silicic volcanism in southern Brazil. Our study in three key 868
areas of low-Ti Caxias do Sul magma sub-types revealed mineralogic composion varies from west, where calcic 869
plagioclase and less ferric pyroxenes are more common to east, where sodic plagioclases and ferric pyroxenes 870
are present. Differences in trace element geochemical features are ascribed to variation in mantle-derived 871
sources and crustal assimilant compositions. Low-Ti silicic volcanics are derived from fractional crystallization of 872
underlying basaltic andesite and assimilation of various lithologies, different in chemical and isotopic 873
composition. Values near 40-50% of fractionation and 40-80% of assimilation, generating the same proportions 874
of mineral assemblages observed in thin sections, agree with previous models for silicic and mafic lavas. 875
The magmatism of Paraná-Etendeka LIP has taken place during early extensional movements of the Gondwana 876
Supercontinent, probably in response to subduction at its margins. Since that, constriction processes responding 877
to a dominant NE-SW extension caused the necking of the continental crust and allowed large amounts of 878
basaltic and silicic magma to achieve the surface. The source of melted mantle could be achieved by 879
decompression melting, reaching the 1,300°C adiabat. The emplacement of silicic low-Ti units in the southern 880
part of the LIP was the last volcanic episode within the southern Paraná basin, culminating in the separation of 881
the continent, believed to have begun at<134 Ma. Absence of important pyroclastic units within the volcanic pile 882
was a fundamental feature for reducing the climate impact of silicic eruptions. 883

CONSIDERAÇÕES FINAIS
A presente tese caracterizou três áreas relevantes no contexto do vulcanismo
ácido do Grupo Serra Geral no Rio Grande do Sul. O reconhecimento de lavas e
condutos associados já havia sido proposto para a área de São Marcos, no entanto
foram agregados o distrito de Flores da Cunha, Mato Perso, e a vasta área dos
municípios de Jaquirana e Cambará do Sul.
No primeiro artigo, “Structures and lithofacies of inferred silicic conduits in the
Paraná-Etendeka LIP, southernmost Brazil”, foram reconhecidas litofácies que
caracterizam condutos alimentadores, como brechas nas porções externas e vitrófiros
bandados e dobrados nas porções internas. Nas lavas foram reconhecidas texturas
coerentes, padrões de vesiculação em sistema fechado e foliação horizontal. As
estruturas regionais de direção NE-, como o lineamento formado pelo leito do rio das
Antas, limitam estruturas de menor porte, de direção NW-, onde ocorrem os
afloramentos de condutos. Os afloramentos de condutos, com 15-25 m, juntamente com
os bandamentos subverticais, estão dispostos majoritariamente de acordo com as
direções NE- e NW-.
O mapeamento geológico na região de Mato Perso, contido no artigo “The Mato
Perso Conduit System: evidence of silicic magma transport in the southern Paraná-
Etendeka LIP”, revelou que: (1) as rochas bandadas e brechadas dos condutos ocorrem
dominantemente entre duas estruturas de direção NW-; (2) Derrames de lavas
oxidadas, de cor vermelha, estão sotopostos aos derrames de lavas não-oxidadas, de cor
cinza; (3) Estruturas similares a diques, com ~4 m de espessura e diques de ~1,5 m de
espessura compõem o sistema de alimentação.
A caracterização do fluxo magmático, presente no artigo “Magmatic flow
patterns in silicic feeder conduits and lava flows from Paraná-Etendeka LIP, Southern
Brazil: AMS fabric, magma transport properties and implications for emplacement”,
sugere que as partes internas dos condutos e das lavas são os locais onde a fábrica
magnética tem o maior potencial de estar paralela ao fluxo magmático, pois a menor
quantidade de vesículas e de fragmentos possibilitou a manutenção fluxo original do
magma, sob baixas viscosidades. Já nas porções externas dos condutos, o dobramento
complexo e a obstrução do fluxo por fragmentos altamente vesiculares deve ser a causa
do espalhamento das direções dos eixos de susceptibilidade. O fluxo nos condutos foi
sub-horizontal, mas com algumas das bandas verticais mostrando fluxo vertical. Nas
lavas o fluxo foi dominantemente horizontal. A direção do fluxo tanto para porções de
alimentação quanto para fluxos de lavas é prevalente nas direções NE-SW e NW-SE.
No último artigo, “Storage and emplacement of low-Ti silicic volcanics in the
southern Paraná-Etendeka LIP: extensional tectonics controlling the ~134 Ma silicic volcanism
in the early stages of Gondwana break-up”, a caracterização da química mineral em cada
área indicou que em Mato Perso e São Marcos os plagioclásios são cálcicos (An>50) e os
piroxênios levemente menos férricos que em Jaquirana-Cambará do Sul, onde os
plagioclásios são sódicos (An<50) e ocorrem com microfenocristais de sanidina. A
matriz vítrea mostra composições similares em todas as áreas, além de trends de
cristalização fracionada quando comparada com as análises de rocha-total. A razão
Zr/Nb é menor nas amostras de São Marcos, sendo sua variação atribuída à
heterogeneidade composicional das fontes derivadas do manto e das rochas
assimiladas. Cálculos de balanço de massa e curvas de assimilação e cristalização são
modelados pelo fracionamento de 40-50% de andesitos basálticos e cristalização de
uma assembleia mineral com proporções similares às observadas em lâmina. O
modelamento de razões de elementos-traço sugere a assimilação de 20-80% de granitos
peraluminosos e ortognaisses com 40-80% de fracionamento. Temperaturas da ordem
de 1000°C, conteúdos de H2O entre 0,5 e 1,3% e viscosidades entre 106 e 103 Pa s foram
calculadas como parâmetros pré- e sin-eruptivos.
Ao final deste artigo, é montado um modelo para a ascensão do magma ácido de
alta temperatura, baixa viscosidade e baixo conteúdo de voláteis. Um cenário tectônico
evidente para a época (~134 Ma) é o de extensão crustal e desmembramento
continental, portanto, sustentando que a reativação de falhas pretéritas por sistemas
transtrativos de larga escala, com movimentação nas direções NW-SE e NE-SW tenham
controlado a ascensão do magma. O modelo final proposto sugere que os movimentos
constritivos da crosta continental em resposta à tectônica Andina e às consequentes
anomalias do manto superior geraram ampla fusão no limite manto-crosta. A fusão
envolveu fontes mantélicas, mas a assimilação de crosta continental foi inevitável,
devido às altas temperaturas mantidas. A eficiência de transporte deste reservatório foi
ampliada devido à extensão progressiva da crosta, fazendo com que o caminho até a
superfície tenha se tornado cada vez mais curto e as taxas de efusão mais altas. Assim, o
transporte de lava até a superfície tornou-se proporcionalmente mais eficiente.
